questions.text: Optic nerve glioma is seen in:(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NF-1 (Neurofibromatosis Type 1)

 

NF-1 is a genetic disorder characterized by the development of multiple noncancerous (benign) tumors of nerves and skin (neurofibromas) and areas of abnormal skin coloration. Among other complications, individuals with NF-1 may develop optic nerve gliomas, which are benign brain tumors that involve the optic nerves. These tumors typically appear in childhood and can cause vision problems.

 

Also seen in NF-1 are Lisch Nodules

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B Tuberous Sclerosis: Tuberous sclerosis is a genetic disorder that causes noncancerous tumors to form in many different organs, primarily in the brain, eyes, heart, kidney, skin, and lungs. While it is associated with a variety of brain tumors, optic nerve gliomas are not a characteristic feature of tuberous sclerosis.

 

Option C Sturge-Weber syndrome: Sturge-Weber syndrome is a rare disorder present at birth, characterized by a port-wine stain birthmark on the face and neurological abnormalities. There is the development of abnormal blood vessels on the brain's surface, but optic nerve gliomas are not typically associated with Sturge-Weber syndrome.

 

Option D Von Hippel-Lindau disease: Von Hippel-Lindau disease is a hereditary condition associated with tumors arising in multiple organs. Hemangioblastomas of the brain, spine, and retina, pheochromocytomas of the adrenal gland, and renal cell carcinomas are common. However, optic nerve gliomas are not commonly seen in this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Optic nerve glioma, is a type of brain tumor that affects the optic nerve, is commonly associated with Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF-1) and not typically seen in Tuberous Sclerosis, Sturge-Weber syndrome, or Von Hippel-Lindau disease.

choices.text: Annular hymen

questions.text: Identify the type of hymen shown in the image? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Septate hymen

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given image is suggestive of the septate hymen.
  • The hymen is the membranous vestige of the junction between the sino-vaginal bulbs and the urogenital sinus, which perforates during fetal life to establish a connection between the vaginal lumen and the perineum.
  • Defective perforation of this structure may result in the following variants of hymen:
    • Imperforate hymen: Without any opening (presents as cryptomenorrhea at puberty)
    • Micro-perforate hymen: Tiny opening
    • Annular hymen: Oval central opening
    • Septate hymen: Two lateral openings partitioned by a bridge of hymenal tissue (May have difficulty in intercourse, placement of a tampon)
    • Naviculate hymen: Boat-like opening

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Imperforate hymen: An imperforate hymen has no opening at all and often presents as cryptomenorrhea (accumulation of menstrual blood behind the hymen) at puberty.

 

Option B. Semilunar hymen: A semilunar hymen has a crescent-shaped opening and is not depicted in the image.

 

Option D. Annular hymen: An annular hymen has an oval central opening and does not match the septate appearance in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A septate hymen is characterized by two lateral openings partitioned by a bridge of hymenal tissue, which may lead to difficulties with intercourse or tampon use.

 

 

Ref: Page no 18, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A boy fell while playing and suffered an abrasion injury on his knees. The dark brown scab will be seen in how many days? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4-7 days

 

Explanation:

 

Abrasions heal in a predictable manner, forming a scab due to drying of blood, serum, and tissue fluids. The color of the scab changes over time, providing a reliable estimate of injury duration:

 

Timeline of Scab Formation in Abrasions

 

  1. Day 1 (Fresh wound) → Bright red due to oozing blood & lymph.
  2. 12-24 hours → Reddish scab begins to form.
  3. 2-3 days → Reddish-brown scab develops.
  4. 4-7 days → Dark brown to black scab appears as the wound dries​
  5. >7 days → Scab begins to peel off, leaving a depigmented area that gradually fades.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Day 1:  Incorrect. Fresh abrasion will appear bright red with oozing blood and lymph, not a dark brown scab.

 

Option B. 2-3 days:  Incorrect. Scab forms but is reddish-brown, not dark brown.

 

Option D. >7 days:  Incorrect. By >7 days, the scab starts falling off, revealing new epithelium underneath.

 

Educational Objective:


Age of Abrasion

choices.text: The dose of telmisartan should be reduced in severe renal failure but not in hepatic failure
The dose of irbesartan should be reduced in case of severe hepatic failure and but not in renal failure
The dose of olmisartan should be reduced in severe liver failure as well as in renal failure
Losartan acts as thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation

questions.text: The true statement among the following is: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Losartan acts as thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation.

 

Losartan is an Angiotensin Receptor Blocker. It binds to the AT1 receptor with high affinity. It is also a competitive antagonist of the thromboxane A2 receptor and attenuates platelet aggregation. All ARBs are avoided in moderate to severe renal impairment due to risk of development of hyperkalemia. Most ARBs require dose adjustment in moderate to severe hepatic impairment also except LEO (Safe in Liver disease are Eprosartan and Olmesartan)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The dose of telmisartan should be reduced in severe renal failure but not in hepatic failure: Like all the ARBs, telmisartan is avoided in severe renal disease. Further, telmisartan is excreted by biliary secretion. So, dose of telmisartan should be reduced in mild to moderate hepatic failure. 

 

Option B. The dose of irbesartan should be reduced in case of severe hepatic failure and but not in renal failure: Irbesartan is avoided in both severe renal and hepatic disease.

 

Option C. The dose of olmisartan should be reduced in severe liver failure as well as in renal failure: Olmesartan require dose adjustment in severe renal failure. However, olmesartan and eprosartan do not require dose adjustment even in severe liver failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

All ARBs should be avoided in moderate to severe renal disease due to risk of hyperkalemia. Except Olmesartan and Eprosartan, all other ARBs require dose adjustment in moderate to severe hepatic disease also. Losartan has additional antiplatelet action by acting as TXA2 receptor antagonist.

questions.text: Which receptor helps in improvement of insulin resistance in Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus with regular exercise and physical activity? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GLUT4

 

GLUT4 is a glucose transporter found primarily in adipose tissues and striated muscles (skeletal and cardiac). It is insulin-dependent, meaning its activity increases in response to insulin. During exercise, the translocation of GLUT4 to the cell membrane is stimulated, enhancing glucose uptake into cells even in the absence of insulin. This mechanism is crucial in improving insulin sensitivity and combating insulin resistance, particularly in individuals with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (DM2). Regular physical activity enhances this effect, leading to better glucose control and reduction of hyperglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GLUT1: This glucose transporter is found in many tissues, including the brain, and is responsible for basal glucose uptake. It is not significantly influenced by insulin and does not play a direct role in improving insulin resistance in DM2.

 

Option C. GLUT2: GLUT2 is primarily found in the liver, pancreas, kidneys, and intestines. It functions in glucose sensing and plays a role in glucose homeostasis but is not directly involved in the insulin-dependent improvement of glucose uptake seen in DM2.

 

Option D. GLUT3: GLUT3 is a high-affinity glucose transporter found predominantly in neurons. It ensures a constant supply of glucose to the brain, but it is not insulin-dependent and does not have a significant role in the management of insulin resistance in DM2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GLUT4 is the insulin-dependent glucose transporter that plays a key role in improving insulin resistance with regular exercise and physical activity.

questions.text: The gold standard investigation for diagnosing endometriosis is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laparoscopy

 

Laparoscopy is considered the gold standard investigation for diagnosing endometriosis. This minimally invasive surgical procedure allows direct visualization of the pelvic organs, enabling the identification of endometriotic lesions.

 

During laparoscopy, biopsies can be taken from suspected areas, which are then examined histologically to confirm the presence of endometriosis.

 

While other imaging techniques, such as transvaginal ultrasound or MRI, can suggest the presence of endometriosis, particularly in the case of endometriotic cysts (also known as chocolate cysts), they may miss smaller or less obvious lesions. Laparoscopy, therefore, provides a definitive diagnosis by allowing direct inspection and biopsy of the lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transvaginal ultrasound: This imaging technique is useful as an initial investigation, especially for detecting endometriotic ovarian cysts, but it is not as comprehensive as laparoscopy for diagnosing all forms of endometriosis.

 

Option B. MRI: MRI can provide detailed images and is useful in some cases, particularly for deep infiltrating endometriosis, but it is not as definitive as laparoscopy.

 

Option C. CT scan: CT scans are not typically used for diagnosing endometriosis due to their lower sensitivity for detecting endometriotic lesions compared to laparoscopy and other imaging modalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laparoscopy is the gold standard investigation for diagnosing endometriosis because it allows direct visualization and biopsy of endometriotic lesions, providing a definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: The National Family Health Survey (NFHS) conducted in 2015-2016 corresponds to which iteration of the survey? [NEET PG 2016]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 4th

 

  • The National Family Health Survey (NFHS) conducted in 2015-2016 was the fourth iteration of the survey. NFHS is conducted every 5-6 years by the International Institute of Population Sciences, Mumbai. 
  • The timeline of the NFHS rounds shows that NFHS-1 was conducted in 1992-93, NFHS-2 in 1998-99, NFHS-3 in 2005-06, NFHS-4 in 2015-16, and the most recent NFHS-5 in 2019-21.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2nd NFHS-2 was conducted in 1998-99, not 2015-16.

 

Option B. 3rd NFHS-3 was conducted in 2005-06, not 2015-16.

 

Option D. 5th NFHS-5 was conducted in 2019-21, not 2015-16.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The National Family Health Survey (NFHS) is India's comprehensive demographic and health survey conducted approximately every 5-6 years, with the fourth round (NFHS-4) conducted in 2015-16, which provided critical data on fertility trends, contraceptive use patterns, and unmet family planning needs across different demographic segments.

questions.text: Cannon ball metastases on chest X-ray are seen in? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Choriocarcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

Cannonball metastases refer to multiple, round, well-circumscribed nodules seen on a chest X-ray, typically representing metastatic deposits. These are characteristic of hematogenous spread to the lungs.

 

 

Choriocarcinoma:

 

Choriocarcinoma is a highly malignant trophoblastic tumor that often follows a molar pregnancy but can also arise after a normal pregnancy or abortion.

 

It is known for its aggressive nature and tendency to metastasize early, particularly to the lungs, where it can cause cannonball metastases.

 

Despite its aggressive nature, choriocarcinoma responds well to chemotherapy, and lung metastases are associated with a relatively good prognosis compared to other metastatic sites.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Complete mole: This refers to a hydatidiform mole, a type of gestational trophoblastic disease, which may precede choriocarcinoma but does not directly present with cannonball metastases.

 

Option C. Invasive mole: This is a type of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia that invades the myometrium but typically does not present with cannonball metastases in the lungs.

 

Option D. Partial mole: This is a type of molar pregnancy with less malignant potential than a complete mole and does not present with cannonball metastases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cannonball metastases on a chest X-ray are a hallmark of choriocarcinoma, representing lung metastases that, despite indicating spread, are associated with a good prognosis due to the tumor's sensitivity to chemotherapy.

questions.text: Deficiency of which of the following causes increased glutamine in blood? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ornithine transcarbamoylase

 

Deficiency of ornithine transcarbamoylase is an X-linked genetic disorder known as ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency (OTC deficiency). This deficiency impairs the urea cycle's function, leading to the accumulation of ammonia and causing hyperammonemia. Elevated ammonia levels can indirectly affect glutamine metabolism, potentially leading to increased glutamine in the blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arginosuccinate lyase: Deficiency of arginosuccinate lyase is associated with argininosuccinic aciduria, a disorder that results in the accumulation of argininosuccinic acid and ammonia. However, this deficiency does not directly lead to increased glutamine levels.

 

Option B. Alpha-galactosidase-A: Deficiency of alpha-galactosidase-A is associated with Fabry disease, a lysosomal storage disorder. It does not lead to increased glutamine levels in the blood.

 

Option D. Arginase: Deficiency of arginase is associated with argininemia, a rare urea cycle disorder. Arginase deficiency leads to the accumulation of arginine and ammonia in the blood. As with OTC deficiency, elevated ammonia levels can indirectly affect glutamine metabolism, potentially leading to increased glutamine in the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency is a urea cycle disorder, which is inherited as an X-linked trait. Hyperammonemia Type II is characterized by OTC deficiency. Mothers also have hyperammonemia and an aversion to high protein diet. To reduce ammonia levels, glutamate combines with ammonia to form glutamine. Thus, elevated levels of ammonia are associated with high glutamine levels in CSF and blood.

 

Urea cycle disorders

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV-positive patient presents with persistent headaches, confusion, and a gradual onset of fever. A lumbar puncture is performed, revealing an elevated opening pressure and a cerebrospinal fluid analysis, showing a positive India Ink stain. What is the most likely diagnosis?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cryptococcus neoformans

 

Explanation:

 

The key points that support the diagnosis of Cryptococcus neoformans meningitis are:

The patient is HIV-positive, indicating an immunocompromised state.

The presentation of persistent headache, confusion, and gradual onset of fever is consistent with meningitis.

 

The lumbar puncture reveals an elevated opening pressure, which is seen in meningitis.

The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis shows a positive India Ink stain, which is a negative stain used to detect capsulated organisms like Cryptococcus neoformans.


Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that commonly causes chronic meningitis in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV.

 

 

Indian Ink Preparation showing Cryptococcus

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial meningitis: While the symptoms and elevated CSF pressure are consistent with bacterial meningitis, the positive India Ink stain indicates the presence of a fungal organism rather than bacteria.

 

Option B. Viral encephalitis: The symptoms and elevated CSF pressure are not typically seen in viral encephalitis, which primarily affects the brain parenchyma rather than the meninges. Additionally, the positive India Ink stain is not consistent with a viral etiology.

 

Option D. Tuberculous meningitis: Although tuberculous meningitis is a chronic form of meningitis, it is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, a bacterium, and would not result in a positive India Ink stain, which is specific for detecting Cryptococcus neoformans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that can cause meningitis in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV.

 

A positive India Ink stain on CSF analysis, along with elevated opening pressure and compatible clinical symptoms, strongly suggests Cryptococcus neoformans meningitis.

questions.text: What type of budding is described by a broad base with a small bud coming off of it, often associated with a figure of 8 appearances? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blastomycosis

 

The term "broad based budding" refers to a type of asexual reproduction in fungi where the bud forms from a broad base rather than a narrow one. This specific budding pattern is characteristic of Blastomycosis, a fungal infection caused by the organism Blastomyces dermatitidis. The appearance of the yeast cells in Blastomycosis is often described as having a broad base with a budding structure that resembles a figure of 8. This visual characteristic is useful in distinguishing Blastomycosis from other fungal infections. The mnemonic "Blasto" helps to remember that "Blasto" implies broad-based budding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cryptococcus: This fungus is known for producing yeast cells with a round, encapsulated appearance and does not exhibit broad-based budding. Instead, it forms a distinctive capsule around the yeast cells which is crucial for its identification.

 

Option C. Candidiasis: The causative agent, Candida species, typically shows pseudohyphae and yeast forms, but these do not have the broad-based budding pattern. Candida's budding is more narrow-based compared to that of Blastomycosis.

 

Option D.Histoplasmosis: Caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, this fungus forms small yeast cells within macrophages. The budding in Histoplasmosis is more narrow-based and does not resemble the broad-based budding pattern described for Blastomycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blastomycosis is characterized by broad-based budding with a figure of 8 appearances, where the term "Blasto" helps recall the broad base nature of the budding structure.

questions.text: A patient presents with cervical lymphadenopathy and is found to be retropositive. A fungal culture depicts a velvety growth with red diffusible pigment on the underside, as shown below. Which is the most likely causative organism? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Talaromyces marneffei

 

The most likely causative organism based on the history and image given is Talaromyces marneffei (Penicillium marneffei).

 

T. marneffei is a dimorphic fungus that causes talaromycosis (penicilliosis). It is commonly seen in individuals with advanced AIDS. It is diagnosed by blood culture, which shows a mold with a powdery surface and characteristic red pigment that diffuses into the agar. Histopathological examination reveals yeast-like organisms with central septation.

 

Clinical features include fever, weight loss, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. Umbilicated papules that resemble molluscum contagiosum may also be seen.

 

Mild and moderate infections can be treated with itraconazole. Amphotericin B is recommended for severe infections.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Blastomyces are thermally dimorphic fungi and cause blastomycosis. Primary infection usually affects the lungs, which can later disseminate through the blood to form multiple abscesses at sites such as skin and bone. Culture at 25-30 degrees Celsius promotes hyphal growth. Microscopic examination of stained specimens shows broad-based budding yeast cells.

 

Option C. Aspergillus colonies have a velvety powdery surface, of which the color varies according to the species. Aspergillus fumigatus is seen as dark green colonies, while Aspergillus niger appears black colored. Yellow-green growth is seen in the case of Aspergillus flavus. On microscopy, dichotomous branching at acute angles seen after staining is characteristic. It can cause invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients.

 

The image below shows Aspergillus niger colonies.

 

 

Option D. Pneumocystis jirovecii cannot be cultured. On being stained by methenamine silver, the cyst wall appears black under the microscope. Trophozoites can also be seen after staining. Clinical features include dyspnea, fever, and cough. It can cause lethal pneumonia in immunocompromised individuals. Diffuse bilateral perihilar interstitial infiltrates can be seen on chest radiograph.

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Recognition of the red diffusible pigment in culture is critical in identifying Talaromyces marneffei infection, particularly in HIV-positive patients. It's important to consider this pathogen when patients from endemic regions present with systemic symptoms and lymphadenopathy. Treatment involves antifungal therapy tailored to the severity of the infection, with agents such as itraconazole for mild cases and amphotericin B for severe cases.

questions.text: A female patient presented with symptomatic urinary symptoms. On laboratory examination, growth of coagulase negative novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus with >10⁴ colony growth is seen. What is the true statement regarding this? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Consider it as a UTI


The patient has symptomatic urinary symptoms, and the laboratory findings indicate the presence of coagulase-negative, novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus with a colony count greater than 10⁴. These characteristics point towards a urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by Staphylococcus saprophyticus, which is known to be novobiocin-resistant and commonly implicated in UTIs, particularly in females. Since the patient is symptomatic, it is important to treat this condition as a UTI rather than dismissing or labeling it as contamination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Take 3 consecutive urine samples: This option is incorrect because taking 3 consecutive urine samples is usually required for parasitic infections, where organisms are intermittently shed in the urine. For bacterial infections like this one, particularly with a significant growth of a specific organism, this is unnecessary.

 

Option B. No treatment required: This is incorrect as the patient is symptomatic. In symptomatic UTIs, especially with a significant colony count of a known pathogenic organism, treatment is essential. Leaving a symptomatic patient without treatment could lead to worsening of symptoms and complications.

 

Option C. It is a contaminated sample: This is incorrect because contamination is typically suggested when there are multiple types of organisms present or a mix of non-pathogenic flora. In this case, the growth of coagulase-negative, novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus is specific and significant, aligning with clinical symptoms, ruling out contamination.

 

Educational Objective:


When a female patient presents with symptomatic urinary symptoms and lab findings show coagulase-negative, novobiocin-resistant Staphylococcus with significant colony growth, it should be considered as a UTI and treated accordingly.

questions.text: In the cadaveric specimen shown, which nerve is marked by the black arrow? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medial pectoral nerve

 

The nerve marked in the image is the medial pectoral nerve. This nerve specifically pierces the pectoralis minor muscle. In the pectoral region, the large muscle visible is the pectoralis major, and when this muscle is cut, the pectoralis minor is seen underneath. The medial pectoral nerve is responsible for innervating both the pectoralis minor and major muscles. The distinguishing feature of this nerve is its penetration through the pectoralis minor muscle, making it identifiable in anatomical images.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thoracodorsal nerve: This nerve supplies the latissimus dorsi muscle and does not have any direct association with the pectoralis muscles or the clavipectoral fascia, making it an incorrect choice in this context.

 

Option B. Lateral pectoral nerve: The lateral pectoral nerve primarily supplies the pectoralis major muscle and pierces the clavipectoral fascia between the clavicle and the pectoralis minor, not the muscle itself. Thus, it is not the nerve marked in the image.

 

Option D. Long thoracic nerve: This nerve supplies the serratus anterior muscle, located along the lateral thoracic wall, and does not pierce the pectoralis minor, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The medial pectoral nerve is the nerve that pierces the pectoralis minor muscle and also provides innervation to the pectoralis major.

questions.text: Which of the following is used as a diagnostic test for CML? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) FISH

 

Explanation

 

Fluorescent In-Situ Hybridization (FISH) is the gold standard for diagnosing Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML). This test detects the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome, which is the result of a translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, creating the BCR-ABL fusion gene. This fusion gene produces a protein with abnormal tyrosine kinase activity, which drives the pathogenesis of CML.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Bone marrow Aspiration: While it can show increased cellularity and myeloid hyperplasia, i.e. help in assessing the extent of disease and marrow involvement but is not definitive for diagnosing CML.

 

Option C. LAP score: Low in CML but also low in other conditions, hence not specific.

 

Option D. Karyotyping: While it can detect chromosomal abnormalities, it is less sensitive compared to FISH for detecting the BCR-ABL fusion gene.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Fluorescent In-Situ Hybridization (FISH) is the gold standard diagnostic test for Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) because it specifically identifies the BCR-ABL fusion gene.

questions.text: A 30-year-old sexually active female presents with painful genital ulcers on her vulva and bilateral painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. The ulcers have irregular edges and a soft base. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chancroid

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi. Key features include:

 

  • Painful genital ulcers
  • Irregular edges with soft base
  • Painful bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy 
  • These ulcers are typically single rather than multiple, and they have irregular edges with a soft base rather than being fluid-filled.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syphilis: Presents with painless ulcer (chancre) and non-tender lymphadenopathy

 

Option C. LGV: Causes painless ulcers with painful lymphadenopathy (buboes)

 

Option D. Genital herpes: Typically presents with multiple, fluid-filled vesicular lesions rather than ulcers with irregular edges

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Chancroid presents with painful genital ulcers having irregular edges and soft base, accompanied by painful bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy.

questions.text: Cherry red spots on retina and mental retardation is seen in: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tay Sach’s disease

 

This is the correct answer. Tay-Sachs disease is characterized by cherry red spots on the retina, which are a distinctive sign of the condition. It is also associated with mental retardation and neurological symptoms. Tay-Sachs is a rare genetic disorder that affects the central nervous system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gaucher's Disease: Cherry red spots on the retina are not a typical feature of Gaucher's disease. Gaucher's disease primarily affects the spleen, liver, and bone marrow, leading to symptoms such as anemia, enlarged liver and spleen, and bone pain.

 

Option C. Hunter Syndrome: Cherry red spots on the retina are not a common feature of Hunter syndrome. Hunter syndrome primarily affects connective tissues and leads to symptoms such as joint stiffness and organ enlargement.

 

Option D. Krabbe’s Disease: Cherry red spots on the retina are not typically seen in Krabbe disease. Krabbe disease is a rare genetic disorder that affects the nervous system and leads to symptoms like muscle weakness and developmental delay.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hallmark feature of Tay-Sachs disease is the presence of "cherry red spots" on the retina of the eye. These spots are a distinctive sign observed during eye examinations. Additionally, individuals with Tay-Sachs disease often experience progressive neurological deterioration, including muscle weakness, loss of motor skills, and seizures. There is also a characteristic decline in cognitive function, leading to intellectual and developmental disability.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 235

questions.text: A man running a 40-kilometre marathon on a hot summer afternoon suddenly collapsed before completing his race. On examination, his body temperature was 104 degrees, but there were no physical signs of dehydration. Which of the following symptoms is least likely to be seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sweating

 

The case scenario is suggestive of a heatstroke in this patient. Heatstroke / heat exhaustion occurs when the body can no longer control its temperature. The body's temperature rises rapidly, the sweating mechanism fails, and the body is unable to cool down. When heat stroke occurs, the body temperature can rise to 106°F or higher within 10 to 15 minutes.

 

In this case it is due to prolonged exposure to the sun during running.

 

Management - Rapidly cooling the body with cold blankets till temperature falls below 102 degrees Celsius.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hot skin: Likely to be present due to the high body temperature in heatstroke.

 

Option B. Hypotension: Can be seen due to vasodilation and possible dehydration.

 

Option D. Disorientation: Likely due to neurological dysfunction caused by the extreme heat affecting the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Cardiac oedema and neuropathy are seen in which of the following vitamin deficiencies? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thiamine

 

Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency is associated with cardiac edema and neuropathy. The deficiency of thiamine can manifest in two main forms:

 

  • Wet beriberi: This form of thiamine deficiency primarily affects the cardiovascular system. It is characterized by symptoms such as tachycardia, cardiomegaly, cardiac failure, and edema. This condition is commonly observed in populations with diets heavily based on polished rice, such as in refugee camps.
  • Dry beriberi: This form affects the nervous system and includes symptoms such as peripheral neuropathy, optic atrophy, ataxia, and irritability.

 

Thiamine deficiency can also lead to complications such as lactic acidosis and Wernicke encephalopathy in adults. The diagnosis can be established by assessing erythrocyte transketolase activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biotin: Biotin deficiency is rare and can be observed in individuals who consume large amounts of raw eggs (which contain avidin that binds biotin) for several months. Symptoms include anorexia, vomiting, dry scaly dermatitis, glossitis, and hypercholesterolemia. It can also occur in patients receiving long-term parenteral nutrition without biotin supplementation.

 

Option C. Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6): Deficiency in pyridoxine is associated with neonatal seizures and other symptoms such as dermatitis, glossitis, and depression, but not specifically with cardiac edema and neuropathy.

 

Option D. Riboflavin (Vitamin B2): Deficiency in riboflavin, known as ariboflavinosis, presents with photophobia, glossitis, angular stomatitis, seborrheic dermatitis, corneal vascularization, and cataracts, but not with cardiac edema and neuropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency is characterized by cardiac edema and neuropathy, manifesting as wet beriberi (cardiovascular symptoms) and dry beriberi (neurological symptoms).

questions.text: A student got his jaw locked while yawning. Identify the muscle attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lateral pterygoid

 

Explanation:

 

The muscle attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint is the lateral pterygoid.

 

The lateral pterygoid muscle has two heads: superior (or upper) and inferior (or lower). The superior head attaches to the articular disc and the capsule of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ). This muscle plays a crucial role in the opening of the mouth, protrusion of the mandible, and moving the jaw from side to side. Dysfunction or spasms of this muscle could contribute to jaw locking during yawning. The lateral pterygoid is, therefore, closely associated with the movements and function of the TMJ.

 

All Innervated by CN V3

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Temporalis: The temporalis muscle originates from the temporal fossa and inserts onto the coronoid process of the mandible. It's primarily responsible for closing the mouth and is involved in elevating and retracting the mandible. It does not attach to the articular disc of the TMJ, but it plays a role in jaw movement.

 

Option C. Medial pterygoid: The medial pterygoid muscle is similar in function to the masseter muscle and helps in elevating the mandible, thus assisting in closing the mouth. It also plays a role in moving the jaw from side to side. However, like the temporalis, it doesn't directly attach to the articular disc of the TMJ.

 

Option D. Masseter: The masseter muscle is one of the primary muscles of mastication (chewing). It originates from the zygomatic arch and inserts onto the lateral aspect of the mandibular angle and ramus. Its primary function is to elevate the mandible, assisting in closing the mouth. It does not have an attachment to the articular disc of the TMJ but is important for jaw function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral pterygoid muscle, particularly its superior head, is uniquely attached to the TMJ's articular disc and plays a pivotal role in jaw movements including mouth opening and lateral movements, making it relevant in cases of jaw locking.

questions.text: Mention the type of joint present at the marked area: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Saddle

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows the hand, with the arrow pointing to the first carpometacarpal joint, which is the joint between the carpal bone (trapezium) and the first metacarpal bone (base of the thumb). This joint is a classical example of a saddle joint.

 

In a saddle joint, one bone has a concave and convex surface that articulates with the complementary convex and concave surface of the other bone, resembling a saddle shape. The joint is surrounded by a capsule and filled with synovial fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ellipsoid: An ellipsoid joint has an oval-shaped articular surface that fits into an elliptical cavity, allowing for biaxial movement. This type of joint is not present at the marked area.

 

Option B. Condylar: A condylar joint has an oval projection of one bone fitting into an elliptical cavity of another bone, allowing for biaxial movement. This type of joint is not present at the marked area.

 

Option C. Plane: A plane joint has two flat or slightly curved articular surfaces that allow for gliding or sliding movements. This type of joint is not present at the marked area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first carpometacarpal joint at the base of the thumb is a saddle joint, allowing a wide range of thumb movements.

Saddle Joint – Mnemonic – PICS

Concavo-convex surface in each bone

P – Patellofemoral joint

I – incudomalleolar joint

C – Carpometacarpal joint

S – Sternoclavicular joint

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby comes with complaints of deafness, cataract, and patent ductus arteriosus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Congenital rubella syndrome

 

The triad of Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), Cataract and Sensorineural Hearing loss (SNHL) points to a diagnosis of Congenital rubella syndrome

 

Rubella causes most severe form of intra uterine infection. If infection sets within 11 weeks POG – 90% defects, if 11-12 weeks – 33% defects chances. More the weeks pass, less is the frequency of having CRS infections.

 

Presentation is similar like measles rash but rash appears on day 1 & lasts for 3 days (3 days measles)

 

Triad – congenital heart disease (MC – PDA; Least Common – ASD), Cataract and Sensorineural Hearing loss (SNHL).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Congenital herpes simplex virus infection: The transmission of HSV to babies usually occurs during delivery in mothers who develop primary genital herpes at that time. Infected babies may be asymptomatic or have fulminant disease. Presents with vesicular eruption on to skin, eyes and mouth. CNS disease that presents as meningitis with seizures and altered sensorium. Diagnosis is by Tzanck smear of the skin lesions, culture or PCR of lesions or cerebrospinal fluid.

 

Option B. Congenital toxoplasmosis: Congenital toxoplasmosis occurs due to maternal primary infection, which is generally subclinical may lead to fetal infection and disease. The transmissibility increases but the risk of fetal disease decreases with advancing pregnancy. It presents with a triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracerebral calcifications.

 

 

Option C. Congenital cytomegalovirus infection: Congenital CMV is reported to be the commonest congenital infection. The overall transmission rate with primary infection is 30% and 10% of all babies infected are symptomatic. Congenital infection can affect all organ systems. Periventricular calcification is characteristic. The diagnosis of congenital CMV is confirmed by a positive IgM in the first two weeks of life.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triad of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), cataract, and sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) is diagnostic of congenital rubella syndrome (CRS).

questions.text: Identify the blocked structure. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Maxillary sinus

 

The image shows a coronal CT scan of the sinuses, where a blocked structure is indicated by the arrow. The blockage appears to be in the maxillary sinus, which is characterized by the presence of an antrochoanal polyp. Antrochoanal polyps originate in the maxillary sinus and extend into the nasal cavity, typically passing through the middle meatus. In this case, the blockage is in the maxillary sinus, as evidenced by the extension of the polyp towards the middle meatus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ethmoid sinus: This is incorrect because the ethmoid sinus is located medially and superiorly to the maxillary sinus and does not match the position of the blockage shown in the image.

  

Option C. Frontal sinus: This is incorrect as the frontal sinus is located above the eyes and towards the forehead, which is not indicated as blocked in the image.

 Option D. Sphenoid sinus: This is incorrect because the sphenoid sinus is located deeper within the skull, behind the ethmoid sinuses, and is not the blocked area shown.

    

Educational Objective:

 

The maxillary sinus can be blocked by an antrochoanal polyp that extends into the nasal cavity through the middle meatus.

choices.text: Subacute combined degeneration of the cord

questions.text: A male patient presents with sensory loss and weakness of limbs for 3 months. He also has angular stomatitis. On examination, there is loss of proprioception, vibration sensations, UMN type of lower limb weakness, and absent ankle reflex. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Subacute combined degeneration of the cord

 

The patient presents with sensory loss, limb weakness, and specific neurological findings that are indicative of subacute combined degeneration of the cord due to vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Key Findings:

 

  1. Sensory Loss and Weakness of Limbs: This suggests a neurological disorder affecting the peripheral and central nervous systems.
  2. Angular Stomatitis: This is often associated with vitamin deficiencies, particularly vitamin B12.
  3. Loss of Proprioception and Vibration Sensation: This is characteristic of posterior column involvement, which is seen in subacute combined degeneration.
  4. UMN Type of Lower Limb Weakness: Upper motor neuron signs (UMN) such as spasticity and exaggerated reflexes, except for the absent ankle reflex, are indicative of corticospinal tract involvement.
  5. Absent Ankle Reflex: This, along with UMN signs, is a classic feature of subacute combined degeneration of the cord.

 

Subacute Combined Degeneration of the Cord: This condition is due to vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to demyelination of the posterior columns and corticospinal tracts. This results in a combination of sensory ataxia, spasticity, and other upper motor neuron signs, except for the absent ankle reflex which indicates peripheral neuropathy.

 

Additional Findings:

 

  • Angular Stomatitis: Points towards a vitamin deficiency.
  • Babinski Positivity with Absent Ankle Jerk: This combination is specifically associated with subacute combined degeneration of the cord due to B12 deficiency. Other conditions like cauda equina syndrome or Friedreich ataxia could present similarly, but the presence of angular stomatitis and the described neurological findings strongly support subacute combined degeneration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extradural Cord Compression: This would typically present with radicular pain and possibly more pronounced lower motor neuron signs below the level of compression, not the UMN signs described here.

 

Option B. Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS): ALS involves both UMN and LMN signs but does not typically present with sensory loss or specific vitamin deficiency signs like angular stomatitis.

 

Option C. Multiple Sclerosis (MS): MS can present with varied neurological signs, but it does not typically present with angular stomatitis or the classic combination of absent ankle reflex with UMN signs seen in subacute combined degeneration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subacute combined degeneration of the cord due to vitamin B12 deficiency presents with sensory loss, UMN signs in the lower limbs, and absent ankle reflex, along with other signs of vitamin deficiency like angular stomatitis.

choices.text: Symptomatic treatment + Treat Vit-A deficiency
Isolation + Symptomatic treatment + Treat Vit-A deficiency
Give MR vaccine + Treat Vit-A deficiency + Treat Vit-A deficiency
Give aspirin for fever + Treat Vit-A deficiency

questions.text: A child has Measles. He presents to OPD at PHC with red congestion of eyes, fever, and coryza. On examination, he has got Bitot spots. Management protocol for this child will be: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isolation + Symptomatic treatment + Treat Vit-A deficiency

 

The child presents with classic symptoms of measles (red eyes, fever, coryza) along with Bitot spots indicating Vitamin A deficiency. The management protocol should include:

 

  • Isolation - since measles is highly infectious
  • Symptomatic management - Supportive care includes adequate hydration, fever management and addressing secondary bacterial infections if present.
  • Treatment of Vitamin A deficiency - WHO recommends Vitamin A supplementation in all children with measles to reduce mortality and prevent ocular complications.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Symptomatic treatment + Treat Vit-A deficiency: Incorrect as it misses isolation, which is crucial to prevent transmission 

 

Option C. Give MR vaccine + Treat Vit-A deficiency + Treat Vit-A deficiency: Incorrect as MR vaccine is not indicated during active measles infection

 

Option D. Give aspirin for fever + Treat Vit-A deficiency: Incorrect as aspirin should be avoided in viral infections in children due to risk of Reye's syndrome

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Management of measles with concurrent Vitamin A deficiency are:

 

  • Isolation
  • Symptomatic treatment 
  • Vitamin A supplementation

questions.text: In a male child having recurrent urinary problems, an imaging as done as shown. What is the management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endoscopic Ablation

 

The image shows dilated posterior urethra suggestive of posterior urethral valves. Posterior urethral valves (PUV) are congenital obstructive lesions in the male urethra that cause significant urinary problems, including recurrent infections, urinary retention, and potential renal damage due to backpressure effects on the kidneys. The preferred management for a significant PUV is endoscopic ablation, also known as cystoscopic ablation. This procedure involves using an endoscope to visualize and ablate (remove) the obstructing valves, thereby relieving the obstruction and improving urinary flow. Endoscopic ablation is the treatment of choice due to its effectiveness in directly addressing the obstructive lesion and preventing further complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dilation of urethra: Urethral dilation may be used in very early or minor cases of PUV but is generally not considered the primary treatment choice due to the risk of recurrence and inadequate relief of obstruction.

 

Option C. Dilation of urethra and bladder: This approach is not appropriate for managing PUV as it does not address the obstructive nature of the valves and is ineffective in resolving the underlying pathology.

 

Option D. Excision of verumontanum: The verumontanum is a structure within the urethra that is not involved in the formation of PUVs, and its excision would not resolve the problem. This option is incorrect and not a part of standard management for PUV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endoscopic ablation is the definitive treatment for posterior urethral valves in children, providing direct relief of the obstruction and reducing the risk of renal damage.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman complains of a creepy crawling sensation in her legs. It is more at night and prevents her from sleeping. She is relieved of these symptoms by either walking or moving her legs. Which of the following drugs is used in treating the condition?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gabapentin

 

The symptoms described by the patient are consistent with restless legs syndrome (RLS). Gabapentin, and pregabalin, belong to the alpha-2-delta calcium channel ligands and have now become the preferred first-line treatments for many patients with RLS due to their effectiveness and good side effect profile.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option A. Pramipexole: Pramipexole and other dopamine agonists were traditionally first-line agents but can have side effects, including augmentation (worsening of RLS symptoms over time with treatment), which makes them less favorable for long-term management.

 

Option C. Vitamin B12: Vitamin B12 is not a standard treatment for RLS.

 

Option D. Iron tablets: Iron tablets may be prescribed if a patient has iron-deficiency anemia, which can exacerbate RLS symptoms. However, they are not the primary treatment for RLS unless this condition is present.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS) is a sensorimotor disorder characterized by an unpleasant sensation in the legs and an urge to move them, especially at night. It can disrupt sleep and may have secondary causes like iron deficiency. Alpha-2-delta calcium channel ligands, such as gabapentin and pregabalin, are first-line treatments.

 

Reference: The Management of Restless Legs Syndrome: An Updated Algorithm Silber, Michael H.Earley, Christopher J. et al. Mayo Clinic Proceedings, Volume 96, Issue 7, 1921 - 1937.

choices.text: MTP can be done only to reduce risk of mother
MTP can be carried up to 24 weeks

questions.text: A victim of sexual assault with 22 weeks of gestation is brought for MTP. Which of these is a true statement? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MTP can be carried up to 24 weeks

 

Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) can be performed up to 24 weeks of gestation under certain circumstances, including cases of sexual assault, rape, or incest, which are recognized as valid grounds for termination under the MTP Act. In cases of pregnancies resulting from such trauma, the law allows MTP up to 24 weeks with the opinion of two registered medical practitioners.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. One Doctor is involved: This is incorrect because for MTP after 20 weeks, the opinion of two doctors is required, not just one.

 

Option B. MTP can be done only to reduce the risk of the mother: This statement is incorrect because MTP is also allowed under other circumstances, such as cases of rape, fetal anomalies, or when the continuation of pregnancy could cause significant physical or mental harm to the woman.

 

Option D. MTP not allowed after 20 weeks: This is incorrect as the MTP Act allows for termination up to 24 weeks under specific conditions, including cases of sexual assault.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MTP can be legally carried out up to 24 weeks in cases of rape, fetal anomalies, and other specific conditions with the opinion of two doctors.

questions.text: In seat belt injury, the most commonly involved organ is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hollow viscus

 

Explanation:

 

Seat belts are known to decrease mortality and prevent head injuries in accidents. However, they can increase the risk of certain abdominal and thoracic injuries.

 

Among all the thoracic and abdominal injuries associated with seat belt use, the maximum damage occurs to three organs: mesentery, omentum, and bowel (hollow viscus). This combination of injuries is known as the "seat belt syndrome." Therefore, the most commonly involved organ in seat belt injury is the hollow viscus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Liver + Spleen: Although liver and spleen injuries can occur in seat belt injuries, they are not the most commonly involved organs compared to the hollow viscus.

 

Option. B. Lungs: While thoracic injuries can be increased due to seat belt use, the lungs are not the most commonly involved organ in seat belt injuries.

 

Option. C. Head of Pancreas: The head of the pancreas is not the most commonly involved organ in seat belt injuries compared to the hollow viscus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In seat belt injuries, the most commonly involved organ is the hollow viscus (bowel), along with the mesentery and omentum, constituting the "seat belt syndrome." Although seat belts are protective and prevent head injuries, they can increase the risk of certain abdominal and thoracic injuries, with the hollow viscus being the most frequently affected.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child came with complaints of fast breathing of RR 48 per minute with no chest in drawing. What is your diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pneumonia

 

According to the IMNCI (Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illness) guidelines, respiratory rate (RR) cutoffs for diagnosing pneumonia in children are as follows:

 

  • Age 0–2 months → RR > 60/min → Fast breathing
  • Age 2 months – 1 year → RR > 50/min → Fast breathing
  • Age 1–5 years → RR > 40/min → Fast breathing

 

The child in the question is 2 years old with a RR of 48/min, which is above the cutoff of 40/min for pneumonia, but there is no chest indrawing or danger signs. This is classified as "pneumonia" according to IMNCI​

 

Classification Based on IMNCI Guidelines:

 

  • No pneumonia (A): Normal breathing rate, no signs of distress.
  • Pneumonia (B) (This Case): Fast breathing (tachypnea) but no chest indrawing or danger signs.
  • Severe pneumonia (C): Fast breathing + chest indrawing or danger signs (e.g., inability to feed, convulsions, lethargy, cyanosis).
  • Very severe pneumonia (D): Not a recognized IMNCI category (IMNCI only classifies pneumonia as "pneumonia" or "severe pneumonia").

 

Educational Objective:

 

A respiratory rate of 48/min in a 2-year-old without chest indrawing is classified as pneumonia. IMNCI guidelines recommend oral amoxicillin for five days as the first-line treatment for non-severe pneumonia.

questions.text: Which syndrome is characterized by the symmetrical enlargement of both lacrimal and salivary glands? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mikulicz's Syndrome

 

Mikulicz's Syndrome is specifically characterized by bilaterally symmetrical enlargement of the lacrimal and salivary glands. This condition is associated with various systemic diseases including leukemias, lymphosarcomas, benign lymphoid hyperplasia, Hodgkin's disease, sarcoidosis, and tuberculosis. This distinct pattern of bilateral glandular enlargement is the hallmark feature that defines this syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sjögren's Syndrome: While Sjögren's syndrome does affect both lacrimal and salivary glands, it presents primarily as an autoimmune chronic inflammatory disease characterized by aqueous deficiency dry eye (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and xerostomia (dryness of mouth), not symmetrical glandular enlargement. It typically occurs in women between 40-50 years of age.

 

Option C. Sturge-Weber Syndrome: This is associated with nevus flammeus (port wine stain), not lacrimal or salivary gland enlargement. It's characterized by facial vascular malformation.

 

Option D. Vogt-Koyanagi Syndrome: This is associated with poliosis (greying of eyelashes and eyebrows) and various ocular conditions, not with lacrimal or salivary gland enlargement.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Mikulicz's Syndrome presents with bilateral symmetrical enlargement of both lacrimal and salivary glands and should prompt investigation for underlying systemic conditions like lymphoproliferative disorders, sarcoidosis, or tuberculosis.

questions.text: The Bragg peak effect is pronounced in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Proton

 

The Bragg peak effect is a phenomenon seen with proton therapy, where there is a sharp increase in radiation dose deposition at a specific depth, followed by a rapid decrease. This makes proton therapy particularly effective for targeting tumors with minimal damage to surrounding tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. X-ray: X-rays do not exhibit the Bragg peak; they deposit radiation relatively uniformly along their path, leading to more widespread tissue damage.

 

Option C. Neutron: Neutrons, while used in certain types of radiation therapy, do not exhibit a Bragg peak. Their interactions are different, primarily involving nuclear reactions.

 

Option D. Electron: Electrons do have a distinct depth-dose distribution, which includes a peak dose at a certain depth, but it is not as sharp or pronounced as the Bragg peak seen with protons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proton beam therapy characteristics:

 

  • It has marked effect with increased depth in the soft tissues.
  • Bragg's peak is their peculiar feature.
  • Ideal agents for treating deep seated tumors.
  • Agent of choice for treatment of clival chordomas.

choices.text: Caters to a population of 1-1.5 lakh
Referral centre for 2- 3 primary health centers
No sub-district and district hospitals present in the area
Should have a 100-bed facility in metro cities

questions.text: Which statement most accurately refers to the requirements for initiating an urban community health center? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Should have a 100-bed facility in metro cities 

 

U-CHC (URBAN - COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTRE)

 

An Urban Community Health Center (U-CHC) is designed to provide inpatient care and other health services in urban areas. According to the IPHS 2022 Guidelines, the requirements for U-CHCs are as follows:

 

  • 30-50 bedded U-CHC providing inpatient care in cities (>1 per 500,000 population)
  • 75-100 bedded U-CHC facilities in metros
  • U-CHC may be set up as a satellite hospital for every 4-5 U-PHCs

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A man exposes his genitalia to a female passerby on the road. This method of deriving sexual gratification by observing the people that look at him nude is best described as? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exhibitionism

 

The given history is suggestive of exhibitionism. Exhibitionism is a condition where an individual derives sexual gratification by exposing their genitalia to unsuspecting people and observing their reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Voyeurism

 

  • Definition: Sexual gratification by watching others, typically women, engaged in sexual activity or in a state of undress. The person engaging in this behavior is known as a "peeping tom."
  • Punishment: Punishable under Section 354(C) IPC.

 

Option B. Fetishism

 

  • Definition: Sexual arousal and gratification are achieved through objects or specific body parts, such as footwear, undergarments, etc., often belonging to the opposite sex.

 

Option D. Masochism

 

  • Definition: Sexual gratification is obtained through experiencing pain or humiliation inflicted upon oneself.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A lady presented to OPD with complaint of pain in the breast. On clinical examination cracks in the nipple were present and fluctuation was positive. Most likely diagnosis in this lady will be? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Breast abscess

 

The patient presents with breast pain, cracked nipples, and a positive fluctuation test. These clinical features are highly suggestive of a breast abscess.

 

  • Cracked nipples: This is a common issue during breastfeeding, leading to an entry point for bacteria. This condition is a significant risk factor for developing infections such as mastitis and abscesses.
  • Fluctuation test positive: This indicates the presence of a fluid-filled cavity, which is characteristic of an abscess.

 

A breast abscess is a localized collection of pus within the breast tissue, usually a complication of mastitis. It presents with a painful, swollen lump in the breast, which may be associated with systemic signs of infection such as fever.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Breast engorgement: This condition involves the painful overfilling of the breasts with milk. It is typically seen in breastfeeding women but does not present with cracked nipples or a positive fluctuation test.

 

Option C. Acute Mastitis: While acute mastitis also presents with breast pain and may occur with cracked nipples, the key distinguishing feature here is the positive fluctuation test, which suggests an abscess rather than simple mastitis. Mastitis without abscess formation usually presents with diffuse redness, swelling, and tenderness without fluctuation.

 

Option D. Atypical hyperplasia: This is a precancerous condition involving abnormal cells in the breast but does not present acutely with pain, cracked nipples, or signs of infection such as a positive fluctuation test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a breastfeeding woman with breast pain, cracked nipples, and a positive fluctuation test, the most likely diagnosis is a breast abscess. This condition is a complication of mastitis and requires appropriate management to prevent further complications.

choices.text: Aortic stenosis and aortic regurgitation

questions.text: Water hammer pulse is seen in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Aortic regurgitation

 

A water hammer pulse, also known as Corrigan pulse, is characterized by a rapid and forceful rise in pulse with a quick collapse. It is typically seen in aortic regurgitation. This phenomenon occurs due to the regurgitation of blood from the aorta back into the left ventricle during diastole, leading to an increased stroke volume and a subsequent forceful arterial pulse that collapses suddenly as the blood quickly flows back into the ventricle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic stenosis: In aortic stenosis, the pulse is described as pulsus parvus et tardus—'small and slow,' reflecting the reduced and delayed pulse wave due to the obstruction across the aortic valve.

 

Option C. Aortic stenosis and aortic regurgitation: When these two conditions coexist, the pulse is known as pulsus bisferiens, which is characterized by a double peak per cardiac cycle—not the rapid rise and fall typical of a water hammer pulse.

 

Option D. Mitral regurgitation: In mitral regurgitation, the pulse may be described as hyperkinetic due to the increased volume load on the left ventricle, but it does not exhibit the rapid collapse seen in water hammer pulse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The water hammer pulse is a distinctive physical finding primarily associated with aortic regurgitation and is useful in the physical diagnosis of this condition. This type of pulse helps clinicians in the assessment of the severity and impact of valve dysfunction on the cardiovascular system.

 

Reference - Harrison/Clinical Cardiology/Chap 239

questions.text: In the IMNCI guidelines for the management of diarrhea, the color code for some dehydration is:(FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Yellow

 

Explanation:

 

In the Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Illnesses (IMNCI) guidelines, diarrhea dehydration is classified into three categories:

 

  • No dehydration – Green – Home management
  • Some dehydration – Yellow – PHC based (MO) – 2 out of 4 criteria

 

Four criteria:

 

  1. Restlessness
  2. Irritability
  3. Sunken eyes
  4. Skin pinch goes back slowly

 

  • Severe dehydration – Pink - Is diagnosed based on the presence of two out of four criteria:

 

  1. Lethargy
  2. Unconsciousness
  3. Sunken eyes
  4. Skin pinch goes back very slowly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the IMNCI guidelines for the management of diarrhea, the color code yellow represents "some dehydration," which is diagnosed based on the presence of two out of four criteria: restlessness, irritability, sunken eyes, and skin pinch goes back slowly.

questions.text: A man with diabetes was on medication and forgot to take his meals before going to the gym. During his workout, he collapsed, and his blood sugar level was found to be 50 mg/dL. Which of the following oral antidiabetic drugs can result in hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glimepiride

 

Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea, a class of oral antidiabetic drugs known to stimulate insulin release from pancreatic beta cells. This action can lead to a decrease in blood glucose levels, which, if not balanced with adequate food intake, can result in hypoglycemia. The patient's low blood sugar level (50 mg/dL) and the scenario of collapsing during a workout indicate that hypoglycemia occurred, likely due to the effect of glimepiride.

 

[Mnemonic: any drug which ends with “ide” can cause hypoglycemia, except glutides (liraglutide), axenatide]

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metformin: Metformin is a biguanide that primarily decreases hepatic glucose production and increases insulin sensitivity. It does not usually cause hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy because it does not stimulate insulin secretion.

 

Option C. Sitagliptin: Sitagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor that increases incretin levels, which in turn increases insulin release and decreases glucagon levels. However, it does not generally cause hypoglycemia as monotherapy because its action is glucose-dependent.

 

Option D. Pioglitazone: Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that increases insulin sensitivity but does not stimulate insulin release. Thus, it does not typically cause hypoglycemia when used alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sulfonylureas, like glimepiride, can cause hypoglycemia, especially when meals are skipped, due to their insulin-stimulating effects.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the demise of a twin in the second trimester, accompanied by maceration? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fetus Papyraceus

 

Fetus papyraceus describes a condition where one twin dies during the second trimester, becomes mummified, flattened, and compressed between the membranes of the living fetus and the uterine wall. The term "papyraceus" derives from the paper-like appearance of the compressed, macerated fetal remains. This can occur in both monozygotic and dizygotic twins but is more common in monozygotic twins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vanishing twin: This phenomenon occurs in the first trimester (typically before 14 weeks) when one embryo/fetus dies and is completely reabsorbed, with no macerated remains visible. The dead fetus simply "vanishes" through resorption rather than becoming compressed and mummified.

 

Option C. Cardiac twin: This is not a recognized clinical term in twin pathology. There is an acardiac twin (in TRAP sequence), but this refers to a living abnormal twin receiving blood from the normal twin, not a demised twin.

 

Option D. Twin-to-Twin transfusion syndrome: This is a complication of monochorionic twin pregnancies where unbalanced blood flow occurs through placental vascular anastomoses. One twin becomes the donor and the other the recipient, but this doesn't specifically refer to fetal demise or maceration.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Fetus papyraceus is the pathological condition where a twin that dies in the second trimester undergoes compression and mummification, presenting as paper-like flattened remains between membranes, distinctly different from early vanishing twin phenomenon.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is least likely to be associated with secondary hemochromatosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH)

 

Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria is least likely to be associated with secondary hemochromatosis because it is characterized by chronic intravascular hemolysis with persistent hemoglobinuria, which actually causes significant iron loss from the body. The hemoglobin released into the urine carries iron away from the body, requiring iron replacement rather than causing iron overload. Only PNH patients receiving long-term blood transfusions while on eculizumab treatment may develop iron overload.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Thalassemia Major: Strongly associated with secondary hemochromatosis due to two mechanisms: regular blood transfusions and ineffective erythropoiesis. Even without transfusions, patients with thalassemia major develop iron overload as ineffective erythropoiesis disrupts hepcidin-mediated regulation of iron absorption, leading to increased intestinal iron uptake.
  • Option B. Sickle Cell Anemia: Patients with severe sickle cell disease often require chronic transfusion therapy, leading to iron overload. The repeated transfusions to manage the disease contribute to secondary hemochromatosis over time.
  • Option C. Hereditary Spherocytosis: While less severe than thalassemia, hereditary spherocytosis involves chronic extravascular hemolysis. When patients require regular transfusions, they can develop iron overload. Even after splenectomy, transfusion-dependent patients remain at risk for hemochromatosis.

     

Educational Objective: 

 

Intravascular hemolysis with hemoglobinuria in PNH causes iron loss, making it the least likely condition to be associated with secondary hemochromatosis, while conditions requiring chronic transfusions (thalassemia major, sickle cell anemia) or causing ineffective erythropoiesis are highly associated with iron overload.

questions.text: Which of the following is autosomal dominant? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Achondroplasia

 

Achondroplasia is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a mutation of the fibroblast growth factor receptor-3 (FGFR-3) gene.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duchene muscular dystrophy – XLR

 

Option A. Cystic fibrosis & Option C. Sickle cell anemia – Autosomal recessive

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is true about this position? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sniffing position for intubation

 

The image illustrates the "sniffing position," which is the ideal position for tracheal intubation. In this position, the patient’s head is elevated and extended at the atlanto-occipital joint, aligning the oral, pharyngeal, and laryngeal axes. This alignment facilitates a direct line of sight during laryngoscopy, making intubation easier. The sniffing position is a standard recommendation for intubating patients under general anesthesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ideal position for Bougie insertion: The sniffing position is primarily recognized for its role in enhancing the view during direct laryngoscopy.

 

Option C. Ideal position for Neurosurgery: This option is incorrect because the sniffing position is not typically used for neurosurgical procedures. Neurosurgery often requires specific head and neck positioning to optimize access to the brain or spine, which differs from the sniffing position.

 

Option D. Neck position for intubation: The term "neck position for intubation" is too vague. The correct terminology for the position depicted in the image is the "sniffing position," which specifically describes the head and neck alignment optimal for intubation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sniffing position aligns the oral, pharyngeal, and laryngeal axes, making it the ideal position for tracheal intubation

questions.text: Tom-Smith arthritis destroys: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Femoral capital epiphysis

 

TOM SMITH ARTHRITIS

 

  • It is septic arthritis of hip in infants which destroy the cartilaginous femoral head rapidly and completely (chondrolysis).
  • It is caused by non-tuberculous bacteria.
  • This intra-articular infection in children peaks in first few years of life with 50% patients younger than 2 years of age.
  • Males affected more than females – 2:1 ratio
  • Hip joint is more commonly involved, followed by knee joint.
  • Risk factors:
    • Prematurity
    • Caesarean section
    • Treatment in NICU
    • Invasive procedures like umbilical/venous catheterization, heel puncture
       
  • Clinical features: 
    • Child presents with limp, unstable gait
    • Shortening of limb
    • Positive telescopy
    • Increased hip movements in all direction
    • Limb position – flexion, abduction, external rotation (FABER)
    • Fever
    • Unable to bear weight
       
  • In 55% cases, no organism is identified.
    • Streptococcus is most commonly seen in neonates
    • Staphylococcus aureus is commonly seen in children over 2 years of age
    • Neisseria gonorrhoeae is commonly seen in adolescents
       
  • Kocher criteria is used for diagnosis:
    • WBC > 12,000 cells/ml of serum
    • Inability to bear weight
    • Fever > 101.3°F
    • ESR > 40 mm/h
    • Additional criteria – CRP (Modified Kocher criteria)
       
  • Investigations:
    • Elevated WBC – leukopenia
    • Elevated ESR – may be normal in early course of infection
    • CRP may increase in first 6-8 hours of infection
    • Hip aspirate will show high WBC, low glucose levels, high lactic acid levels
       
  • Radiographic findings:
    • X-ray may be normal in early stages
    • Shows widening of joint space, subluxation/dislocation

 

 

  • Treatment: 
    • Non-operative: antibiotics
    • Operative: surgical irrigation and debridement followed by IV antibiotics
       
  • Prognosis:
    • Good prognosis
    • Delayed diagnosis may result in permanent joint damage and long-term disability. 
    • Long-term morbidity includes acetabular dysplasia, subluxation and dislocation, cartilage necrosis, limb length discrepancy, abnormal/premature closure of proximal femoral physis, ischemic necrosis, and complete destruction of femoral head
    • Poor prognostic factors:
      • Age < 6 months
      • Associated osteomyelitis
      • Delay of > 4 days until presentation
      • Hip joint involvement

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acetabular roof. Acetabular roof lesions are uncommon in children. If they occur, their cause can be eosinophilic granuloma, ewing’s sarcoma, non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, metastases, and neuroblastoma.

 

 

Option C. Femoral neck. Femoral neck is affected in children in femoral neck fractures due to high-impact injuries, but this is uncommon. Benign bone tumors or tumor-like bone lesions in the femoral neck can also be the cause.

 

Option D. Greater trochanter. Avulsion fractures of greater trochanter are very rare in children. They can be secondary to gluteal muscle contraction, femoral neck fracture, hip dislocation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tom smith arthritis or the septic arthritis in children, most commonly affects the femoral capital epiphysis.

choices.text: Police not under rank of sub inspector

questions.text: In the civil negligence case against a doctor who bears the onus of proof? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Patient

 

“Onus of proof” implies the responsibility to prove or disprove a crime.

 

As a general rule, the onus to proof lies with the victim (or his lawyer), and not with the accused, in both civil and criminal cases. The accused is assumed to be innocent. It is the responsibility of victim (or his lawyer) to prove that accused has done a crime.

 

In criminal case, the burden of proof is always on the state (i.e., the public prosecutor, the government lawyer for victim). The state must prove that the accused is guilty.

 

In civil case, the burden of proof lies on the plaintiff. The plaintiff is a person who brings a case against another in a civil court. The person against whom the case is filed is called defendant. For e.g. in a medical negligence case, the patient is the plaintiff and the doctor is the defendant. Ordinarily the patient (and his lawyer) has to prove that the Doctor is negligent.  

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Police not under rank of sub inspector: Involved in criminal investigations but does not bear the onus of proof in civil negligence cases.

 

Option C. Magistrate: Presides over legal proceedings but does not bear the onus of proof.

 

Option D. Doctor: The doctor is the defendant in a negligence case and does not bear the initial burden of proof.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exceptions where onus of proof lies with accused:

 

  • RES IPSA LOQUITOR (the thing or action speaks of itself)
  • Insanity: If the defendant wishes to claim that he/she is insane, and therefore not guilty, the defendant bears the burden of proving his/her insanity.
  • 114-A CrPc: In a case of rape, where sexual intercourse by the accused is proved and the question is whether it was without the consent of the woman alleged to have been raped, the court shall presume that she did not consent. The accused will have to prove that it was with consent.
  • Contributory Negligence: If a doctor wants to take the defense of contributory negligence, then he will have to prove that the patient was also negligent along with him.

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman presents with thrombocytopenia (platelet count < 50,000) and fragmented RBCs in a peripheral smear. Which of the following is the least likely differential diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Evan's syndrome.

 

Evan's syndrome is characterized by the combination of autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) with immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) and would be the least likely diagnosis in this case. Evan's syndrome features both conditions simultaneously but does not typically present with fragmented RBCs, which are characteristic of microangiopathic hemolytic anemias. The peripheral smear in Evan's syndrome would show spherocytes from the autoimmune hemolytic component rather than schistocytes (fragmented RBCs).

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP): TTP is characterized by thrombocytopenia and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia with schistocytes (fragmented RBCs). The pentad of TTP includes microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, renal failure, neurologic findings, and fever. Pregnancy can be a triggering factor for TTP, making this a very plausible diagnosis in this clinical scenario.
  • Option B. Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC):  DIC is a common complication in pregnancy, particularly with obstetric complications like abruptio placentae, amniotic fluid embolism, and retained dead fetus syndrome. DIC presents with thrombocytopenia and fragmented RBCs (schistocytes) due to microvascular thrombi. The condition involves abnormal activation of coagulation processes, consumption of clotting factors, and secondary fibrinolysis.
  • Option C. HELLP syndrome: HELLP (Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets) syndrome is a serious pregnancy complication that features microangiopathic hemolytic anemia with fragmented RBCs and thrombocytopenia. It typically occurs in the third trimester and is considered part of the spectrum of preeclampsia, making it a highly likely diagnosis in this pregnant patient.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Fragmented RBCs (schistocytes) on peripheral blood smear indicate a microangiopathic hemolytic process (as seen in TTP, DIC, and HELLP), whereas Evan's syndrome presents with spherocytes due to its autoimmune hemolytic component without microangiopathy.

choices.text: Normal vaginal delivery
Forceps delivery

questions.text: A primigravida presents to the emergency room in the early stage of labor with adequate uterine contractions. On per vaginal examination, a gynecoid pelvis is felt, the membranes are ruptured, and the vertex is felt in the right occipito-posterior position. How will you manage this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Normal vaginal delivery

 

Explanation:

 

  • Normal vaginal delivery:
    • Assuming the patient has no other complications, such as fetal distress or cephalopelvic disproportion, the given features of right occipito-posterior presentation with a favorable pelvis (gynecoid) and adequate uterine contractions can be managed by normal vaginal delivery.
    • In 90% of circumstances with a favorable pelvis and strong uterine contractions, without any complications, the occipito-posterior position can undergo the mechanism of normal labor.
    • The patient can be closely monitored for the progress of normal vaginal delivery. However, if complications arise or labor stalls, alternative methods such as vacuum-assisted delivery or forceps delivery may be considered. A cesarean section would only be necessary if there were complications that prevented a safe vaginal delivery.

 

Other Options:
