Option A. Vacuum-assisted delivery: Vacuum-assisted delivery is generally considered when there is prolonged second stage of labor or fetal distress. In this case, since there are no complications mentioned and the pelvis is favorable, normal vaginal delivery is the preferred option.

 

Option B. Cesarean section: A cesarean section is usually considered when there is cephalopelvic disproportion, fetal distress, or failure to progress in labor. Given the favorable conditions in this scenario, a normal vaginal delivery is feasible.

 

Option D. Forceps delivery: Forceps delivery, like vacuum-assisted delivery, is used in cases of prolonged second stage of labor or when there is a need to expedite delivery. In the absence of such complications, normal vaginal delivery is the appropriate management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right occipito-posterior presentation with a favorable pelvis and adequate uterine contractions in a primigravida can be managed by closely monitoring for a normal vaginal delivery, provided there are no complications.

 

Ref: Page 89, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Identify the condition that presents with painful vesicles as shown below: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Herpes simplex virus

 

The condition shown in the image is characterized by painful vesicles, which is a hallmark of herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. HSV causes fluid-filled vesicles that are often painful, and these lesions can occur on the skin or mucous membranes, including genital areas. The vesicles eventually rupture, forming shallow, painful ulcers. HSV can present as recurrent outbreaks, especially during periods of stress or weakened immune function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidiasis: Candidiasis typically presents with white, curd-like discharge and redness, particularly in mucous membranes like the mouth or vagina. It does not cause vesicles or painful ulcers.

 

Option B. Syphilis: Syphilis typically presents with a painless chancre in the primary stage, followed by a rash and other systemic symptoms in later stages. Vesicles are not a feature of syphilis.

 

Option C. Chancroid: Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, presents with painful genital ulcers but does not form fluid-filled vesicles. The ulcers are more ragged and deeper compared to those seen in HSV infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Painful vesicles are characteristic of herpes simplex virus infection. Remember the association of HSV with painful, fluid-filled vesicles, especially in genital or mucosal areas.

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) presents to the OPD with seizures, headache, vomiting, and photophobia. On further evaluation, homonymous hemianopia and episodes of epilepsy were observed. A CT scan of the brain was performed What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Temporal abscess

 

Explanation: 


The presentation indicates temporal lobe abscess because:

 

  • Clear space-occupying lesion in temporal lobe visible on CT
  • Classic symptoms of temporal lobe involvement: 
    • Seizures indicating brain parenchymal involvement
    • Homonymous hemianopia due to temporal lobe compression
    • Increased intracranial pressure symptoms (headache, vomiting, photophobia)
  • Common complication of CSOM due to: 
    • Direct extension through tegmen tympani

    • Temporal lobe is most common site for brain abscess in CSOM

       

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Meningitis

 

  • Most common intracranial complication of CSOM
  • No discrete abscess formation on imaging
  • Shows meningeal enhancement
  • Different clinical features (neck rigidity, Kernig's sign)

 

Option C. Subdural abscess

 

  • Collection between dura and arachnoid
  • Different imaging appearance
  • No discrete parenchymal involvement
  • Different clinical presentation

 

Option D. Extradural abscess

 

  • Collection outside dura but intracranial
  • Different imaging appearance
  • Less severe neurological symptoms
  • No parenchymal involvement

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Temporal lobe abscess is a serious complication of CSOM, presenting with seizures and characteristic CT findings of a space-occupying lesion in the temporal lobe.

questions.text: A 14-year-old child presents with intellectual disability and a history of self-mutilation. Which of the following tests would be most helpful in establishing the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serum Uric Acid Levels

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of intellectual disability combined with self-mutilation strongly suggests Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. This genetic disorder is characterized by a complete deficiency of HGPRT (hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase) enzyme. HGPRT deficiency leads to markedly elevated uric acid levels due to disrupted purine metabolism. The condition presents with neurological manifestations including self-mutilation (typically lip and finger biting), intellectual disability, and spasticity, along with signs of hyperuricemia such as gout and renal problems.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum Lead Levels: While lead poisoning can cause intellectual disability, it does not typically cause self-mutilation behavior. Lead toxicity presents with abdominal pain, peripheral neuropathy, and anemia.

 

Option B. Serum Alkaline Phosphatase Levels: This would be elevated in bone disorders, liver disease, or growth disorders, none of which typically present with the combination of intellectual disability and self-mutilation.

 

Option C. Serum Lactate Dehydrogenase Levels: LDH elevation is seen in conditions involving tissue damage or rapid cell turnover such as hemolysis, myocardial infarction, or certain malignancies, not in conditions causing self-mutilation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome presents with the characteristic triad of hyperuricemia, self-mutilating behavior, and neurological dysfunction including intellectual disability; serum uric acid measurement is a key diagnostic test for this condition.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Pneumothorax? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreased Chest Expansion.

 

Explanation:

 

In pneumothorax, air accumulates in the pleural space, causing the lung to collapse away from the chest wall. This leads to decreased chest expansion on the affected side. The physical examination findings in pneumothorax typically include an enlarged hemithorax with no breath sounds, hyperresonance to percussion, and potentially a mediastinal shift to the contralateral side in tension pneumothorax.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased Breath Sounds: pneumothorax causes diminished or absent breath sounds on the affected side due to air in the pleural space separating the lung from the chest wall, preventing normal sound transmission.

 

Option C. Increased Vocal Resonance: pneumothorax actually decreases vocal resonance. The presence of air in the pleural space impedes sound transmission, resulting in decreased, not increased, vocal resonance.

 

Option D. Dull percussion note: pneumothorax produces a hyperresonant percussion note due to the presence of air in the pleural space. A dull percussion note would suggest fluid (as in pleural effusion) or consolidation (as in pneumonia).

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Pneumothorax presents with classic physical findings of decreased chest expansion, absent breath sounds, and hyperresonant percussion on the affected side - the opposite of findings seen with pleural fluid or consolidation.

choices.text: Help with PET scan units for diagnosis of cancer

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about cancer treatment according to the Colombo plan? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Setting up cobalt therapy units

 

The Colombo Plan, established in 1950, was drawn up for the cooperative economic development of South and South-East Asia. It included 20 countries with the main aim of improving the living standards of people. The plan focused on industrial and agricultural development and provided support for health promotion, mostly through fellowships.

 

Key Contributions of the Colombo Plan:

 

  • AIIMS, New Delhi: Established with financial assistance from New Zealand.
  • Cobalt Therapy Units: Canada supplied cobalt therapy units to medical institutions in India as part of the Colombo Plan. These units significantly enhanced the capabilities for cancer treatment in India.

 

Cobalt Therapy Units:

 

  • Cobalt Therapy: Involves using gamma rays from cobalt-60 isotopes to treat cancer. It was a crucial development in radiotherapy in the mid-20th century and improved cancer treatment outcomes significantly.
  • Provision under Colombo Plan: The supply of cobalt therapy units by Canada helped Indian medical institutions upgrade their cancer treatment facilities, making advanced radiotherapy accessible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under the Colombo Plan, Canada supplied cobalt therapy units to medical institutions in India, significantly enhancing the country's capacity to provide advanced cancer treatment through radiotherapy. This was a crucial step in improving healthcare infrastructure and cancer treatment capabilities in India.

questions.text: Full form of JSSK is? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram


JSSK stands for Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram. It was introduced as an extension of the Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY), which was launched in 2005 under the National Rural Health Mission. The older name of JSY was National Maternity Benefit Scheme.

 

Initially, JSY focused only on maternal health, emphasizing the safety and wellbeing of the mother (Janani). However, recognizing the interconnected nature of maternal and newborn health, the program was expanded to include newborn care (Shishu), leading to the creation of JSSK on June 1, 2011 under NRHM. JSSK aims to provide free and cashless services to pregnant women and sick newborns, including transport, medicines, and diet, focusing on enhancing the overall health of both mother and child (upto 1 year of age).

 

Educational Objective:
 

JSSK stands for Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram, focusing on the protection and care of both the mother and infant by providing comprehensive healthcare services

choices.text: Difference in the axial length of the eyeballs
Difference in the size of corneas
Difference in the size of pupils
Difference in the size of images formed by the two eyes

questions.text: What does aniseikonia refer to? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Difference in the size of images formed by the two eyes

 

Aniseikonia is defined as a condition wherein the images projected to the visual cortex from the two retinae are abnormally unequal in size and/or shape. Up to 5% aniseikonia is well tolerated by the visual system. The term specifically refers to the difference in image size perception between the two eyes, not the physical difference in ocular structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Difference in the axial length of the eyeballs: This is incorrect. While differences in axial length may cause anisometropia (unequal refractive error between eyes), it is not aniseikonia. Anisometropia can lead to aniseikonia, but they are distinct conditions. Anisometropia refers to the optical state when the total refraction of the two eyes is unequal.

 

Option B. Difference in the size of corneas: This is incorrect. Different corneal sizes may contribute to refractive differences between eyes but don't directly define aniseikonia. Aniseikonia specifically refers to the perceived image size difference, not the anatomical difference in corneal dimensions.

 

Option C. Difference in the size of pupils: This is incorrect. Pupil size differences (anisocoria) affect light entry but not image size perception. Pupils regulate light entry to the eye but don't significantly impact the size of images formed on the retina or perceived by the visual cortex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aniseikonia represents a perceptual phenomenon where the brain receives differently sized images from each eye, which can result from optical correction of anisometropia, retinal displacement, or cortical processing differences. It's a critical concept in understanding visual discomfort in patients with high refractive correction differences between eyes.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient who is non-compliant with medication presents to you with sudden onset breathlessness. A chest X-ray was done, which is shown below. How will you manage this patient? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Intravenous nitroglycerin

 

The patient presents with symptoms and signs indicative of pulmonary edema, which is evident from the chest X-ray showing interstitial edema and classic bat-wing appearance, suggestive of cardiogenic pulmonary edema. The history of hypertension and non-compliance with medication supports the diagnosis, as poorly controlled hypertension can lead to increased afterload, left ventricular failure, and subsequent pulmonary edema.

 

Intravenous nitroglycerin: Nitroglycerin is the treatment of choice in this scenario as it helps to reduce both preload and afterload by dilating veins and arteries. This leads to a reduction in pulmonary congestion and improvement in symptoms of breathlessness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous salbutamol: Salbutamol is a bronchodilator used primarily in the treatment of asthma or COPD exacerbations, and primarily not used intravenously. It is not indicated for managing pulmonary edema and does not address the underlying cause of fluid accumulation in the lungs.

 

Option C. Nebulization with salbutamol: Similar to intravenous salbutamol, nebulized salbutamol is used for bronchodilation in conditions like asthma or COPD. It is not effective in treating pulmonary edema and does not relieve the symptoms caused by fluid overload in the lungs.

 

Option D. Oxygen and antibiotics: While oxygen might be necessary to support the patient’s respiratory status, antibiotics are not indicated unless there is a concurrent infection, which is not suggested by the patient’s presentation. The primary issue here is fluid overload due to heart failure, not an infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of cardiogenic pulmonary edema, intravenous nitroglycerin is essential to reduce preload and afterload, thereby alleviating pulmonary congestion and improving the patient's symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used for induction of anesthesia in pediatric patients? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Desflurane

 

  • Desflurane is a highly pungent gas, and its use for inhalational induction can lead to airway irritation, coughing, breath-holding, and even laryngospasm, especially in pediatric patients.
  • Therefore, desflurane is not typically used as an induction agent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Halothane: Due to its pleasant odor and rapid onset, Halothane was historically a popular choice for inhalational induction in children. However, concerns regarding hepatotoxicity and arrhythmias have reduced its usage in modern practice.

 

Option B. Sevoflurane: Sevoflurane is one of the most commonly used agents for inhalational induction in pediatric patients due to its non-irritating nature and rapid kinetics.

 

Option D. Nitrous Oxide: Nitrous oxide is often used as an adjunct to other inhalational anesthetics for both induction and maintenance of anesthesia. It has a rapid onset and is generally well-tolerated by pediatric patients. It can be used for inhalational induction, especially in combination with more potent agents like sevoflurane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Desflurane is not typically used for the induction of anesthesia in pediatric patients due to its pungent nature, which can cause significant airway irritation and laryngospasm.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids is likely to aggregate on the surface of a globular protein circulating in the plasma? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lysine

 

Explanation: 

 

Lysine would likely aggregate on the surface of a globular protein circulating in plasma because it is a hydrophilic amino acid with a positively charged side chain. In proteins that exist in aqueous environments like blood plasma, hydrophilic amino acids tend to orient toward the outside surface where they can interact favorably with water. This arrangement forms part of the tertiary structure of globular proteins, where hydrophilic residues face outward while hydrophobic residues cluster in the interior.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Leucine: This is a nonpolar, hydrophobic amino acid with a  aliphatic side chain. Hydrophobic interactions drive amino acids like leucine into the interior of globular proteins to shield them from the surrounding water molecules, not to the surface.

 

Option C. Isoleucine: Similar to leucine, isoleucine is nonpolar and hydrophobic. It would be found predominantly in the protein's core rather than on its surface, as part of the "hydrophobic core" that stabilizes tertiary structure.

 

Option D. Valine: Another nonpolar, hydrophobic amino acid that would be driven to the interior of a globular protein rather than being exposed on the surface in an aqueous environment.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The distribution of amino acids in globular proteins follows the principle that hydrophilic residues (like lysine) are positioned on the surface to interact with the aqueous environment, while hydrophobic residues (like leucine, isoleucine, and valine) cluster in the interior to minimize unfavorable interactions with water.

questions.text: Apolipoprotein B 48 is a made of:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) RNA editing

 

 ApoB-48 is produced through RNA editing. RNA editing involves the modification of the nucleotide sequence of an RNA molecule, specifically the conversion of a cytosine (C) to a uracil (U) in the mRNA. In the case of ApoB-48, this editing changes a codon, resulting in the synthesis of a shorter protein product.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RNA Alternate Splicing: RNA alternate splicing is a process where different exons (coding regions) of a pre-mRNA are combined in various ways to generate different mature mRNA molecules. This process can result in the production of different protein isoforms, but it is not the mechanism for generating ApoB-48.

 

Option C. DNA Editing: DNA editing typically refers to genetic engineering techniques that modify the DNA sequence, such as CRISPR-Cas9. This is not the process by which ApoB-48 is generated.

 

Option D. RNA Interference: RNA interference (RNAi) is a cellular process involved in gene regulation, where small RNA molecules inhibit gene expression. It does not play a direct role in the synthesis of ApoB-48.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In liver cell, Apo B100 gene gives rise to Apo B 100 protein. But Apo B48 protein is made in intestinal cells from the gene encoding Apo B100, by the process of RNA editing, which is also known as Differential RNA processing or chemical modification of RNA. This is a post transcriptional modification.

 

Ref- Harper 31st ed pg – 238

choices.text: Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair
Indirect hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a noticeable bulge in his lower abdomen that becomes more pronounced when he's in a standing position. Upon examination, hernia is identified located medial to the inferior epigastric artery. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what would be the appropriate management? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair

 

  • The given clinical scenario of a hernia medial to the inferior epigastric artery is suggestive of a direct hernia.
  • Direct inguinal hernias protrude through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal and are located medial to the inferior epigastric artery.
  • The appropriate surgical method for the management of a direct hernia is the Lichtenstein mesh repair.
  • The Lichtenstein mesh repair is a tension-free technique that uses a synthetic mesh to reinforce the weakened area of the abdominal wall.
  •  It is the preferred method for direct hernias due to its lower recurrence rates and faster recovery times.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct hernia and Bassini repair: While the Bassini repair is a traditional method of hernia repair, it involves suturing the transversus abdominis and internal oblique musculoaponeurotic arches or conjoined tendon to the inguinal ligament without using a mesh. This technique is mainly used in cases of hernial strangulation and peritonitis but has a high recurrence rate compared to mesh repairs.

 

Option C. Indirect hernia and Bassini repair: Incorrect. Indirect hernias are located lateral to the inferior epigastric artery and are managed differently. The Bassini repair, as mentioned, is less commonly used today due to its higher recurrence rates compared to mesh repairs.

 

Option D. Indirect hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair: Incorrect. While the Lichtenstein mesh repair can also be used for indirect hernias, the scenario describes a direct hernia based on its location medial to the inferior epigastric artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A direct inguinal hernia is characterized by its location medial to the inferior epigastric artery, and the Lichtenstein mesh repair is the recommended surgical approach due to its efficacy and lower recurrence rates.

questions.text: A woman presents with white vaginal discharge. On preparing a vaginal smear, pseudo hyphae are seen. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Candidiasis

 

The presence of pseudohyphae on a vaginal smear is indicative of a fungal infection, specifically candidiasis. Candida species, most commonly Candida albicans, are known to form pseudohyphae as part of their growth pattern. This finding, along with white vaginal discharge, supports the diagnosis of candidiasis.

 

Candidiasis: Characterized by white, thick, curd-like vaginal discharge and the presence of pseudohyphae and spores on microscopy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trichomonas: Identified by the presence of flagellated protozoa (Trichomonas vaginalis) on the smear.

 

Option C. Bacterial vaginosis: Diagnosed by the presence of clue cells on the smear, which are vaginal epithelial cells coated with bacteria, giving a stippled appearance.

 

Option D. Physiological: Normal vaginal discharge, which shows normal vaginal epithelial cells without any pathogenic organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of pseudo-hyphae on a vaginal smear with white discharge is diagnostic of candidiasis.

questions.text: All of the following species of Borrelia are associated with tick-borne relapsing fever, except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Borrelia recurrentis

 

Explanation:

 

Borrelia recurrentis is associated with louse-borne relapsing fever (epidemic relapsing fever), not tick-borne relapsing fever. This organism is transmitted by the human body louse (Pediculus humanus corporis) and causes epidemic relapsing fever. The disease manifests as recurring episodes of fever separated by periods of apparent recovery, hence the name "relapsing fever." B. recurrentis is the only species in this group that uses lice as its vector rather than ticks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Borrelia hermsii - This species causes endemic (tick-borne) relapsing fever. It is transmitted by soft ticks and is one of the common causes of tick-borne relapsing fever in North America.

 

Option C. Borrelia turicatae - This species causes tick-borne relapsing fever and is transmitted by soft ticks of the genus Ornithodoros. It is endemic in certain regions and belongs to the tick-borne group of relapsing fever Borrelia.

 

Option D. Borrelia duttonii - This species causes tick-borne relapsing fever in Africa. It is transmitted by the soft tick Ornithodoros moubata and causes endemic relapsing fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Borrelia recurrentis is the only species among those listed that causes louse-borne epidemic relapsing fever, while the other species (B. hermsii, B. turicatae, and B. duttonii) cause tick-borne endemic relapsing fever.

questions.text: Which disease is represented by the submerged portion of the iceberg in the iceberg model? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Influenza

 

The iceberg model represents diseases that have a visible portion (the tip) and a hidden portion (submerged part). The tip of the iceberg represents clinical cases that are easily diagnosed by healthcare providers, typically through visible symptoms. The submerged portion, which is much larger, represents the hidden cases, including asymptomatic, subclinical, latent, and pre-symptomatic individuals who still carry the disease but are not easily visible to healthcare providers.

 

Influenza exhibits the iceberg phenomenon because many individuals with the virus remain undiagnosed as they show mild or no symptoms. These hidden cases contribute significantly to the spread of the disease as these individuals do not seek medical attention and thus remain below the surface of clinical observation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tetanus: Tetanus does not exhibit the iceberg phenomenon because it does not have carriers or asymptomatic cases. The disease only manifests as clinical cases, which are visible to healthcare providers.

 

Option B. Measles: Measles does not have an iceberg phenomenon due to the absence of carriers and asymptomatic cases. It is typically a visible disease with noticeable symptoms once infection occurs.

 

Option C. Rubella: Similar to measles, rubella also does not have an iceberg phenomenon as it does not involve carriers or hidden cases. The infection is primarily identified through its clinical presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The iceberg phenomenon describes diseases with a significant proportion of hidden, asymptomatic, or subclinical cases, such as influenza, which contribute to disease transmission.

 

Remember – No carriers – No iceberg Phenomena – Measles, Rubella, Rabies, Tetanus and + Pertussis

questions.text: Which of the following can be prevented by folic acid supplementation in pregnancy? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neural tube defects

 

Folic acid supplementation before conception and during early pregnancy significantly reduces the risk of neural tube defects (NTDs) in the developing fetus. Neural tube defects are serious birth defects of the brain and spine, such as spina bifida and anencephaly. Adequate folic acid intake is crucial during the early stages of pregnancy, often before a woman even knows she is pregnant, which is why supplementation is recommended for all women of childbearing age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anemia: While folic acid can help in the prevention of certain types of anemia, such as megaloblastic anemia, it is not the primary preventive measure for anemia during pregnancy, which is more commonly addressed with iron supplementation.

 

Option B. Preeclampsia: Preeclampsia is a pregnancy complication characterized by high blood pressure and damage to other organ systems. There is no strong evidence that folic acid supplementation alone can prevent preeclampsia.

 

Option D. Gestational diabetes: Gestational diabetes is a type of diabetes that develops during pregnancy. Folic acid supplementation is not known to prevent gestational diabetes; its primary preventive role is in reducing the risk of neural tube defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folic acid supplementation before and during early pregnancy is essential to prevent neural tube defects in the developing fetus.

questions.text: During psychotherapy, the therapist had mixed conscious and unconscious feelings towards his patient. This is known as? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Countertransference

 

Countertransference refers to the therapist's emotional reactions, both conscious and unconscious, towards a patient, often influenced by the therapist's own past.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transference: Transference is when the patient unconsciously redirects feelings experienced in an earlier relationship to the therapist.

 

Option C. Dissociation: Dissociation is a disconnection and lack of continuity between thoughts, memories, surroundings, actions, and identity.

 

Option D. Dissociation: Preoccupation is being absorbed in thought, typically about something particular.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Transference refers to the redirection of a patient's feelings and attitudes from past experiences or individuals onto the therapist, typically operating on an unconscious level. Countertransference represents the therapist's emotional reactions to a patient, both conscious and unconscious. These reactions may be influenced by the therapist's own personal history, unresolved conflicts, or reactions to the patient's transference.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 1069

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common end-product of fatty acid synthesis pathway? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Palmitic acid

 

Palmitic acid is the most common end-product of fatty acid synthesis. It is a saturated fatty acid with 16 carbon atoms and is a major product of de novo fatty acid synthesis in the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arachidonic acid: Arachidonic acid is not the most common end-product of fatty acid synthesis. It is a polyunsaturated fatty acid that can be synthesized from linoleic acid, which is an essential fatty acid.

 

Option B. Oleic acid: Oleic acid is not the most common end-product of fatty acid synthesis. It is a monounsaturated fatty acid that can be synthesized within the fatty acid synthesis pathway but is not the most common end product.

 

Option D. Acetyl CoA: Acetyl CoA is not an end-product of fatty acid synthesis. It is a starting substrate for fatty acid synthesis, as fatty acids are synthesized by adding two-carbon units (acetyl groups) to a growing fatty acid chain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fatty acids are synthesized from acetyl CoA mainly by a de novo synthetic pathway operating in the cytoplasm referred to as extramitochondrial or cytoplasmic fatty acid synthase system.

 

The major fatty acid synthesized de novo is palmitic acid, the 16C saturated fatty acid. The process occurs in liver, adipose tissue, kidney, brain, and mammary glands.

 

Beta oxidation of fatty acids breaks it down into Acetyl CoA.

 

 

Defect in pathway - Inhibition of lipogenesis occurs in type 1 (insulin-dependent) diabetes mellitus, and variations in its activity affect the nature and extent of obesity.

questions.text: Which of the following is the least common feature of Multiple Myeloma? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyperviscosity syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

In multiple myeloma, the paraproteins are typically IgG or light chains, which cause hyperviscosity only at extremely high concentrations. Most multiple myeloma patients do not develop serum paraprotein levels high enough to cause clinical hyperviscosity syndrome, making it the least common feature among those listed.

 

Other Options: 

 

  • Option A. Bone pain: Incorrect. Bone pain is one of the most common presenting symptoms of multiple myeloma, affecting approximately 70% of patients at diagnosis. The pain results from osteolytic lesions and pathologic fractures caused by increased osteoclast activity.
  • Option B. Normocytic Normochromic Anemia: Incorrect. Anemia is present in about 70% of newly diagnosed multiple myeloma patients. The anemia is typically normocytic and normochromic, resulting from bone marrow infiltration by plasma cells and inhibition of erythropoiesis.
  • Option C. Susceptibility to bacterial infection: Incorrect. Increased susceptibility to infections is a hallmark feature of multiple myeloma due to hypogammaglobulinemia of normal immunoglobulins and impaired immune function. Patients commonly experience recurrent bacterial infections, particularly with encapsulated organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While bone pain, anemia, and increased infection risk represent cardinal features of multiple myeloma present in most patients, hyperviscosity syndrome occurs relatively rarely and requires extremely high paraprotein levels to become clinically significant.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient visits you with inflammatory alopecia. This type of hair loss is commonly associated with which variant of tinea capitis infection? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Favus and Kerion

 

Favus and kerion are the inflammatory variants of tinea capitis.

 

Tinea capitis variants:

 

 

Kerion presents in Children with boggy swelling, easily pluckable hair, with regional lymphadenopathy. It is a severe inflammatory type of tinea capitis. The. In severe cases, there may be pus along with sinus formation.

 

Kerion:

 

 

  • Lesion: boggy indurated scalp swelling
  • Easily pluckable hair associated with regional lymphadenopathy
  • Most common causative organisms:  Zoophilic dermatophytes i.e., T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes.
  • Investigation: 10% KOH mount
  • Treatment: DOC overall and for Microsporum àGriseofulvin

 

Note: DOC for Trichophyton is Terbinafine.

 

Other Options

 

Option A: Endothrix and Favus and Option D: Kerion and Endothrix Endothrix infections involve the growth of fungi within the hair shaft without external spore formation and typically present with less inflammation compared to Kerion and Favus.

 

Option B: Ectothrix and Endothrix Ectothrix infections, where the fungus grows on the outside of the hair shaft and breaks the hair off at the scalp surface, are typically associated with non-inflammatory forms of alopecia such as the 'grey patch' type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inflammatory alopecia is commonly associated with the favus and kerion variants of tinea capitis, which can cause scarring and permanent hair loss due to the significant inflammatory response.

 

 

Reference:  Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Page no 32.39-40, 89.35

choices.text: Total body water is more than adults

questions.text: Dehydration usually affects an infant’s more than adults. Which of the following is a true statement in this scenario related to infants / Newborn? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ECF more than ICF

 

Explanation:

 

In newborns/infants, the ECF is greater than ICF, which makes them more susceptible to dehydration. 

 

  • ECF is greater than ICF in newborns
  • At 3-4 months of age, ICF equals ECF (50:50)
  • After 3-4 months, ICF gradually increases while ECF decreases
  • This higher ECF makes infants more vulnerable to fluid losses and dehydration

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ICF more than ECF: Incorrect. Because in newborns, ECF is higher than ICF. ICF becomes greater than ECF only after 3-4 months of age.

 

Option C. Total body water is more than adults: Incorrect. Because while newborns have a higher percentage of total body water (75%) compared to adults (60%), the absolute amount of water is less in newborns due to their smaller body size.

 

Option D. ECF equals ICF: Incorrect. Because ECF equals ICF only at around 3-4 months of age, not in newborns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In newborns, extracellular fluid (ECF) volume is greater than intracellular fluid (ICF) volume, which makes them more susceptible to dehydration compared to adults.

questions.text: TB test done only on whole blood sample is:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Interferon gamma release assay

 

TB test done on a whole blood sample is the interferon-gamma release assay. It has been used for the diagnosis of latent tuberculosis in patients with HIV (who frequently have a negative Mantoux test).

 

Interferon-gamma release assays include:

 

  • QuantiFERON-TB Gold
  • T-SPOT.TB

 

QuantiFERON-TB Gold quantitates the amount of IN- produced by CD4+ T cells in response to the antigens from Mycobacterium tuberculosis. QuantiFERON-TB Gold Plus (QFT- Plus) is an improved version of the QuantiFERON-TB Gold test. QuantiFERON-TB Gold detects only TB-specific CD4+ responses. However, QuantiFeron-TB Gold Plus detects both CD8+ and CD4+ T-cell responses to TB-specific antigens.

 

T-SPOT.TB determines the total number of individual effector T cells expressing IFN-v.

 

The TrueNat TB test is a new molecular test that can diagnose TB in one hour as well as test for rifampicin resistance. This test uses a sputum sample taken from the patient. Only about 0.5 ml of the sample is required. Gene Xpert is also a molecular method of testing that cannot use blood as a sample.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TrueNat TB: Incorrect, as this molecular test diagnoses TB and tests for rifampicin resistance using a sputum sample, not whole blood.

 

Option B. Gene Xpert: Incorrect, this is another molecular test that identifies TB and resistance to rifampicin but also uses sputum samples rather than whole blood.

 

Option D. All of the above: Incorrect, as only the interferon gamma release assay is designed to be used with whole blood samples.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Interferon gamma release assay is a valuable tool for diagnosing latent TB, particularly suitable for patients who may not be effectively diagnosed through traditional skin tests, offering a sensitive and specific method that utilizes whole blood to detect an immune response to TB antigens.

choices.text: Increased nicotine levels may elevate sympathetic tone.
Increased carboxyhaemoglobin levels may cause a rightward shift in the oxyhaemoglobin dissociation curve.
Reduced pulmonary capacity can result from diminished ciliary function and decreased surfactant production.
The risk of infection is heightened due to impaired immune function.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the impact of smoking on a chronic smoker scheduled for elective surgery is incorrect? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased carboxyhaemoglobin levels may cause a rightward shift in the oxyhaemoglobin dissociation curve.

 

Smoking increases carboxyhaemoglobin levels, which causes a leftward shift of the oxygen dissociation curve. This leftward shift means hemoglobin holds onto oxygen more tightly, impairing oxygen delivery to tissues. Smoking cessation for at least 12 hours before surgery decreases carboxyhaemoglobin levels, shifting the curve rightward and improving tissue oxygenation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased nicotine levels may elevate sympathetic tone: Nicotine stimulates sympathetic activity, which increases the risk of arrhythmias during anesthesia. Reduced nicotine levels from smoking cessation decrease this risk.

 

Option C. Reduced pulmonary capacity can result from diminished ciliary function and decreased surfactant production:  Smoking impairs ciliary function, increases mucus production, and reduces surfactant, leading to reduced pulmonary capacity.

 

Option D. The risk of infection is heightened due to impaired immune function: Smoking suppresses immune response, making infections more likely, especially in the postoperative period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Smoking increases carboxyhaemoglobin, causing a leftward shift of the oxygen dissociation curve and impairing oxygen delivery. Smoking cessation (even just 12 hours before surgery) helps reverse this effect and improves tissue oxygenation.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy comes with complaints of left ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, painful swallowing, and fever. The oral cavity examination reveals the following. The external facial examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is likely? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Quinsy

 

The image shows quinsy also known as a peritonsillar abscess.

 

It is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

 

The clinical features are sore throat/ dysphagia, drooling of saliva, trismus, ipsilateral otalgia, and fever.

 

EXAMINATION FINDINGS

 

  1. The tonsil, pillars and soft palate on the involved side are congested and swollen. Tonsil itself may not appear enlarged as it gets buried in the oedematous pillars
  2. Uvula is swollen and oedematous and pushed to the opposite side.
  3. Bulging of the soft palate and anterior pillar above the tonsil.
  4. Mucopus may be seen covering the tonsillar region.
  5. Cervical lymphadenopathy is commonly seen. This involves jugulodigastric lymph nodes.
  6. Torticollis. Patient keeps the neck tilted to the side of abscess

 

Investigations - Contrast-enhanced CT or MRI shows the abscess and its extent. Needle aspiration of an abscess provides material for culture and sensitivity of bacteria.

 

The management of quinsy is by antibiotics and incision & drainage to drain the abscess followed by interval tonsillectomy 6 weeks later.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pharyngitis: Typically presents with a sore throat and possible fever but lacks the severe localized symptoms and findings of quinsy.

 

Option B. Parotid abscess: Would likely present with swelling and pain in the parotid gland area, externally visible.

 

Option C. Bezold's Abscess: An infection that spreads from the mastoid process into the surrounding tissues, which would involve more distinct signs of ear and mastoid involvement.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Quinsy is a severe infection requiring prompt recognition and treatment to prevent complications. It distinctly affects the peritonsillar area, leading to significant local and systemic symptoms that guide its diagnosis and management.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 299

questions.text: Multiple Lisch nodules are a feature of which of the following conditions? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neurofibromatosis

 

Lisch nodules are melanocytic hamartomas found on the iris and are a hallmark of Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). They are usually benign and do not affect vision. However, their presence is a key diagnostic criterion for NF1. Neurofibromatosis is a genetic disorder characterized by the development of multiple noncancerous (benign) tumors of nerves and skin (neurofibromas), cafe-au-lait macules (light brown skin spots), and skin fold freckling. Another significant feature is plexiform neurofibroma, which can present congenitally.

 

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tuberous sclerosis: This is incorrect. Tuberous sclerosis is characterized by different skin lesions such as hypomelanotic macules (ash leaf spots), facial angiofibromas, and Shagreen patches. Lisch nodules are not associated with this condition.

 

Option C. Leprosy: This is incorrect. Leprosy (Hansen's disease) primarily affects the skin, nerves, and mucous membranes, but it does not involve the development of Lisch nodules.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis: This is incorrect. Sarcoidosis is a multisystem inflammatory disease characterized by the formation of granulomas, often affecting the lungs and lymph nodes, but not associated with Lisch nodules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lisch nodules are pigmented iris hamartomas specific to Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) and are an important diagnostic feature of this condition.

questions.text: A 41-year-old construction worker in Uttar Pradesh collapsed at the construction site in the afternoon of a summer day. Which of the following is least likely to be seen? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sweating

 

The scenario describes a case of classic heat stroke, which is a medical emergency characterized by an elevated core body temperature (often above 104°F or 40°C) and central nervous system dysfunction due to exposure to high environmental temperatures.

 

Sweating is typically absent in classic heat stroke. This is because the body’s thermoregulatory mechanisms fail, and the skin becomes hot and dry. In contrast, in exertional heat stroke (which occurs during intense physical activity), sweating may still be present.

 

Other Options:

 

In classic heat stroke, particularly due to prolonged exposure to high environmental temperatures:

 

Option A. Temperature of 105°F: It is common to have very high body temperatures in heat stroke.

 

Option C. Hypotension: Can occur due to dehydration and vasodilation.

 

Option D. Tachypnea: Increased respiratory rate is a compensatory mechanism to help cool the body and deal with metabolic demands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In classic heat stroke, typically caused by high environmental temperatures, the patient often presents with high body temperature, hypotension, and tachypnea, but lacks sweating. This distinguishes it from exertional heat stroke, where sweating might still be present.

questions.text: A pregnant lady with a history of recurrent abortions is now diagnosed to have antiphospholipid syndrome. What would be the best mode of treatment for her? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aspirin + heparin

 

Explanation

 

Aspirin + heparin:

 

  • Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by recurrent pregnancy loss, thrombosis, and the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies.
  • The primary cause of pregnancy loss in APS is believed to be due to inhibition of trophoblast function and differentiation, which leads to placental dysfunction.
  • The best management approach for pregnant women with APS includes:
    • Low dose aspirin: Initiated as soon as pregnancy is confirmed. Aspirin helps by preventing platelet aggregation and improving blood flow to the placenta.
    • Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH): Started once fetal cardiac activity is detected. LMWH helps prevent blood clot formation, thus reducing the risk of thrombosis and improving pregnancy outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin only: While low-dose aspirin is beneficial, it is not sufficient alone for the prevention of complications in APS. The addition of heparin provides better protection against thrombosis and pregnancy loss.

 

Option C. Aspirin + heparin + steroids: Steroids are not routinely used in the management of APS during pregnancy due to their potential side effects and lack of evidence showing added benefit in preventing pregnancy loss when combined with aspirin and heparin.

 

Option D. Aspirin + steroids: Similar to the previous option, steroids are not recommended as part of the standard management for APS in pregnancy. The combination of aspirin and heparin is the preferred treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best management for pregnant women with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) to prevent recurrent pregnancy loss includes low-dose aspirin and low molecular weight heparin (LMWH).

 

Ref: Page no 2907, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is the hallmark of "shock lung"? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Diffuse alveolar damage

 

Explanation: 

 

Diffuse alveolar damage (DAD) is the hallmark histopathological finding in shock lung, also known as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) or hyaline membrane disease. ARDS is characterized by acute respiratory failure with bilateral pulmonary opacities caused by non-cardiac pulmonary edema. Histologically, DAD is characterized by the formation of hyaline membranes (made of fibrin and dead epithelial cells) lining the alveolar ducts, along with capillary congestion, necrotic alveolar epithelial cells, interstitial and intra alveolar edema, and inflammatory cell infiltration. This pattern develops in response to various insults including sepsis, trauma, pneumonia, and other conditions causing acute lung injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alveolar proteinosis - This is characterized by the accumulation of surfactant-like lipo proteinaceous material in the alveoli. It is not associated with shock lung or ARDS but occurs in primary or secondary pulmonary alveolar proteinosis.

 

Option B. Bronchiolitis obliterans - This refers to inflammation and fibrosis of bronchioles leading to their obstruction. It's associated with chronic conditions like chronic rejection in lung transplants or connective tissue diseases, not with acute shock lung.

 

Option C. Desquamative interstitial pneumonia - This is a type of smoking-related interstitial pneumonia characterized by accumulation of pigmented macrophages within alveolar spaces. It is not the pattern seen in shock lung/ARDS.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Diffuse alveolar damage characterized by hyaline membrane formation is the pathological hallmark of acute respiratory distress syndrome ("shock lung"), representing the common endpoint of various forms of acute lung injury.

questions.text: What is the most common site for a peripheral arterial aneurysm? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Popliteal

 

Explanation:

 

The popliteal artery is the most common site for peripheral arterial aneurysms. Popliteal aneurysms account for approximately 70% of all peripheral aneurysms and are classically diagnosed in males in their seventh decade of life. They are bilateral in about 50% of cases. An important clinical consideration is that one-third of patients with popliteal aneurysms also have abdominal aortic aneurysms, necessitating abdominal examination in these patients.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Axillary: Axillary artery aneurysms are rare compared to popliteal aneurysms and often occur secondary to trauma or arteritis.
  • Option C. Subclavian: Subclavian artery aneurysms are uncommon and may be associated with thoracic outlet syndrome or trauma but occur much less frequently than popliteal aneurysms.
  • Option D. Superficial femoral: While femoral aneurysms do occur, they are less common than popliteal aneurysms. True aneurysms of the femoral artery are relatively uncommon.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Popliteal artery aneurysms are the most common peripheral arterial aneurysms, with significant risk of complications when exceeding 20mm in diameter, requiring consideration for surgical repair to prevent thrombosis, distal embolization, or rupture.

questions.text: What is the reservoir of leishmaniasis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Man

 

Explanation:

 

The reservoir of visceral leishmaniasis, also known as kalazar or Indian kala-azar, is humans.

 

  • Visceral leishmaniasis (kalazar) is caused by the parasite Leishmania donovani.
  • The vector responsible for transmitting the disease is the sandfly (Phlebotomus species).

 

 

  • The reservoir host of the disease is humans (man).

 

Other 3 options are incorrect

 

Educational Objective:

 

For visceral leishmaniasis (kalazar or Indian kala-azar), the reservoir host is humans.

questions.text: The patient is having the following hand movements. Which of the following conditions is responsible?  (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypercarbia

 

Explanation

 

The hand movements shown in the image are characteristic of asterixis or flapping tremors, which is a form of negative myoclonus.

 

Asterixis is most commonly associated with hepatic encephalopathy but can also be seen in other conditions such as hypercarbia (CO2 narcosis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thyrotoxicosis: This condition typically presents with fine tremors rather than the flapping tremors seen in asterixis.

 

Option C. Hemiballismus: This condition involves violent, involuntary movements of one side of the body, not the flapping tremors associated with asterixis.

 

Option D. Hypoxia: While hypoxia can cause various neurological symptoms, it is not specifically associated with asterixis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asterixis, or flapping tremors, is a form of negative myoclonus often associated with hepatic encephalopathy and hypercarbia (CO2 narcosis). Recognizing these characteristic hand movements can help identify underlying conditions such as hypercarbia. ​

questions.text: Identify the stage of the pressure sore:  (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4

 

A stage 4 pressure sore is characterized by full-thickness tissue loss with exposed bone, tendon, or muscle. The image shows a deep ulcer with visible bone and extensive tissue damage, which are hallmarks of a stage 4 pressure sore. This stage represents the most severe form of pressure ulcer, with significant risk for infection and complications due to the depth of tissue involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage 1: This stage involves non-blanching erythema of intact skin. It is the earliest stage of pressure ulceration, where the skin appears red and does not turn white when pressed.

 

Option B. Stage 2: Stage 2 pressure sores involve partial-thickness skin loss with exposure of the dermis. They may appear as shallow, open ulcers with a red or pink wound bed, without slough or deeper tissue exposure.

 

Option C. Stage 3: Stage 3 sores show full-thickness skin loss, where subcutaneous fat may be visible but bone, tendon, or muscle are not exposed. The ulcer may include undermining and tunneling but does not extend into deeper structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stage 4 pressure sores are the most advanced, involving full-thickness tissue loss with visible bone, muscle, or tendon. Early identification and treatment of pressure sores can prevent progression to this severe stage.

choices.text: Wait until TB culture results to start ATT

questions.text: A 35-year-old homeless man presented with a 1-month history of fever, cough, and weight loss. Both sputum smears turned out to be negative, but the chest x-ray ordered was suggestive of tuberculosis. According to the recent NTEP guidelines, which is the next best line of management? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Ask for CBNAAT

 

According to the National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) guidelines, the next step in managing a patient with a high clinical suspicion of tuberculosis (TB), a suggestive chest x-ray, and negative sputum smears is to perform a CBNAAT (Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test). CBNAAT is a molecular test that detects the DNA of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and can also identify rifampicin resistance, providing rapid and accurate results.

 

DIAGNOSTIC TESTS UNDER NTEP:

 

1. Sputum smear Microscopy

  • ZN staining
  • LED – FM

 

2. Culture

 

  • LJ Medium
  • Automated Liquid culture (ALC)
    •  BACTEC MGIT 960
    • BACTALERT
    • VERSATREK

 

3. Drug sensitivity testing

 

  • Moderate Proportionate Sensitivity testing PST MGiT 960
  • Economic proportionate sensitivity testing 1% LJ Medium

 

4. Molecular Diagnosis test:

  • Line Probe Assay
    • LPA TB
    • PL LPA– INH & Rifampicin Resistance
    • SL LPA-FQ / SLI Resistance
    • NAAT
    • CBNAAT
    • True NAT True NAT
  • Developed by ICMR Real time PCR Technology 
    • True NAT MTB- MTB
    • True NAT MTB plus- MTB
    • True NAT MTB Dx- Rifampicin Resistance TEP:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeat sputum smears: Is not appropriate since the patient already had two negative sputum smears and a chest x-ray suggestive of tuberculosis.

 

Option C. CBNAAT: Should be performed first than Line probe assay.

 

Option D. TB: Culture takes time to yield results, the patient may deteriorate in the meantime.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following features is not part of the classic triad of congenital toxoplasmosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hepatosplenomegaly

 

The classic triad of congenital toxoplasmosis includes:

 

  1. Chorioretinitis – Inflammation of the retina and choroid, causing visual impairment.
  2. Intracranial Calcifications – Diffuse calcifications, commonly in the basal ganglia.
  3. Hydrocephalus – Ventricular enlargement due to CSF flow obstruction.

 

Hepatosplenomegaly, although commonly seen in congenital infections, is not a part of the classic triad of congenital toxoplasmosis​FMGE Jan 2025 pediatrics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital toxoplasmosis classically presents with the triad of chorioretinitis, intracranial calcifications, and hydrocephalus. Additional findings such as hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, and seizures may occur but are not part of the classic triad.
